DIV1.P: The Roaring Girle. OR Moll Cut-Purse.
As it hath lately beene Acted on the Fortune-stage by the Prince his Players.
Written by T. Middleton and T. Dekkar.

FIGURE.P: My case is alter'd, I must worke for my liuing.

DIV1.P: Printed at London for Thomas Archer, and are to be sold at his shop in Popes head-pallace, neere the Royall Exchange. 1611.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Comicke, Play-readers, Venery, and Laughter.
DIV1.P:
THE fashion of play-making, I can proper∣ly compare to nothing, so naturally, as the alteration in apparell: For in the time of the Great-crop-doublet, your huge bombasted plaies, quilted with mighty words to leane purpose was onely then in fashion. And as the doublet fell, neater inuentions beganne to set vp. Now in the time of sprucenes, our plaies followe the nicenes of our Garments, single plots, quaint conceits, letcherous iests, drest vp in hanging sleeues, and those are fit for the Times, and the Tearmers: Such a kind of light-colour Summer stuffe, mingled with diuerse colours, you shall finde this published Comedy, good to keepe you in an afternoone from dice, at home in your chambers; and for venery you shall finde enough, for sixepence, but well coucht and you marke it. For Ve∣nus being a woman passes through the play in doublet and breeches, a braue disguise and a safe one, if the Sta∣tute vnty not her cod-peece point. The book I make no question, but is fit for many of your companies, as well as the person itselfe, and may bee allowed both Gallery roome at the play-house, and chamber-roome at your lodging: worse things I must needs confesse the world
ha's taxt her for, then has beene written of her; but 'tis the excellency of a Writer, to leaue things better then he finds 'em; though some obscoene fellow (that cares not what he writes against others, yet keepes a mysticall bau∣dy-house himselfe, and entertaines drunkards, to make vse of their pockets, and vent his priuate bottle-ale at mid-night) though such a one would haue ript vp the most nasty vice, that euer hell belcht forth, and presented it to a modest Assembly; yet we rather wish in such discoueries, where reputation lies bleeding, a slackenesse of truth, then fulnesse of slander.

LG.L: A Play (expected long) makes the Audience looke
For wonders:—that each Scoene should be a booke,
Compos'd to all perfection; each one comes
And brings a play in's head with him: vp he summes,
What he would of a Roaring Girle haue writ;
If that he findes not here, he mwes at it.
Onely we intreate you thinke our Scoene.
Cannot speake high (the subiect being but meane)
A Roaring Girle (whose notes till now neuer were)
Shall fill with laughter our vast Theater,
That's all which I dare promise: Tragick passion,
And such graue stuffe, is this day out of fashion.
I see attention sets wide ope her gates
Of hearing, and with couetous listning waites,
To know what Girle, this Roaring Girle should be.
(For of that Tribe are many.) One is shee
That roares at midnight in deepe Tauerne bowles,
That beates the watch, and Constables controuls;
Another roares i'th day time, sweares, stabbes, giues braues,
Yet sells her soule to the lust of fooles and slaues.
Both these are Suburbe-roarers. Then there's (besides)
A ciuill Citty▪ Roaring Girle, whose pride,
Feasting, and riding, shakes her husbands state,
And leaues him Roaring through an yron grate.
None of these Roaring Girles is ours: shee flies
VVith wings more losty. Thus her character lyes,
Yet what neede characters? when to giue a gesse,
Is better then the person to expresse;
But would you know who 'tis? would you heare her name?
Shee is cal'd madde Moll; her life, our acts proclaime.

LIST.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.
LIST.ITEM: Sir Alexander Wentgrane, and Neats-foot his man.
Iacke Dapper, and Gull his page.

SP.STAGE: Enter Mary Fitz-Allard disguised like a sempster with a case for bands, and Neatfoot a seruingman with her, with a napkin on his shoulder, and a trencher in his hand as from table.

SP.SPEAKER: Neatfoote.
SP.P: THe yong gentleman (our young maister) Sir Alexanders sonne, is it into his eares (sweet Damsell) (embleme of fragility) you desire to haue a message transported, or to be tran∣scendent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.P: A priuate word or two Sir, nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.P: You shall fructifie in that which you come for: your pleasure shall be satisfied to your full contentation: I will (fairest tree of generation) watch when our young maister is erected, (that is to say vp) and deliuer him to this your most white hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: Thankes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.P: And withall certifie him, that I haue culled out for him (now his belly is replenished) a daintier bit or modicome then any lay vpon his trencher at dinner—hath he notion of your name, I beseech your chastitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: One Sir, of whom he be spake falling bands.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.P: Falling bands, it shall so be giuen him,——if you please to venture your modesty in the hall, amongst a curle∣pated company of rude seruingmen, and take such as they can set before you, you shall be most seriously, and ingeniously welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: I haue dyed indeed already sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.P: ——Or will you vouchsafe to kisse the lip of a cup of rich Orleans in the buttry amongst our waiting women.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: Not now in truth sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.P: Our yong Maister shall then haue a feeling of your being here presently it shall so be giuen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: I humbly thanke you sir, but that my bosome
Is full of bitter sorrowes, I could smile,
To see this formall Ape play Antick tricks:
But in my breast a poysoned arrow stickes,
And smiles cannot become me, Loue wouen sleightly
(Such as thy false heart makes) weares out as lightly,
But loue being truely bred ith the soule (like mine)
Bleeds euen to death, at the least wound it takes,
The more we quench this, the lesse it slakes: Oh me!

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: A Sempster speake with me, saist thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.P: Yes sir, she's there, viua voce, to deliuer her auricular confession.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: With me sweet heart. What ist?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: I haue brought home your bands sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Bands: Neatfoote.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Prithee look in, for all the Gentlemen are vpon rising.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.L: Yes sir, a most methodicall attendance shall be giuen.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: And dost heare, if my father call for me, say I am busy with a Sempster.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.P: Yes sir, hee shall know it that you are busied with a needle woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: In's eare good Neat-foote,

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.L: It shall be so giuen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: Bands, y'are mistaken sweete heart, I bespake none, when, where, I prithee, what bands, let me see them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: Yes sir, a bond fast sealed, with solemne oathes,
Subscribed vnto (as I thought) with your soule:
Deliuered as your deed in sight of heauen,
Is this bond canceld, haue you forgot me.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Ha! life of my life: Sir Guy Fitz-Allards daughter,
What has transform'd my loue to this strange shape?
Stay: make all sure,—so: now speake and be briefe,
Because the wolfe's at dore that lyes in waite,
To prey vpon vs both albeit mine eyes
Are blest by thine, yet this so strange disguise
Holds me with feare and wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: Mines a loathed sight,
Why from it are you banisht else so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I must cut short my speech, in broken language,
Thus much sweete Moll, I must thy company shun,
I court another Moll, my thoughts must run,
As a horse runs, thats blind, round in a Mill,
Out euery step, yet keeping one path still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: Vmh: must you shun my company, in one knot
Haue both our hands byt'h hands of heauen bene tyed,
Now to be broke, I thought me once your Bride:
Our fathers did agree on the time when,
And must another bed-fellow fill my roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Sweete maid, lets loose no time, tis in heauens booke
Set downe, that I must haue thee: an oath we tooke,
To keep our vowes, but when the knight your father
Was from mine parted, stormes began to sit
Vpon my couetous fathers brow: which fell
From them on me, he reckond vp what gold
This marriage would draw from him, at which he swore,
To loose so much bloud, could not grieue him more.
He then diswades me from thee, cal'd thee not faire,
And askt what is shee, but a beggars heire?
He scorn'd thy dowry of (5000) Markes.
If such a summe of mony could be found,
And I would match with that, hee'd not vndoe it,
Prouided his bags might adde nothing to it,
But vow'd, if I tooke thee, nay more, did sweare it,
Saue birth from him I nothing should inherit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: What followes then, my ship-wracke.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Dearest no:
Tho wildly in a laborinth I go,
My end is to meete thee: with a side winde
Must I now saile, else I no hauen can finde
But both must sinke for euer. There's a wench
Cal'd Mol, mad Mol, or merry Moll, a creature
So strange in quality, a whole citty takes
Note of her name and person, all that affection
I owe to thee, on her in counterfet passion,
I spend to mad my father: he beleeues
I doate vpon this Roaring Girle, and grieues
As it becomes a father for a sonne,
That could be so bewitcht: yet ile go on
This croked way, sigh still for her, faine dreames,
In which ile talke onely of her, these streames
Shall, I hope, force my father to consent
That heere I anchor rather then be rent
Vpon a rocke so dangerours, Art thou pleas'd,
Because thou seest we are way-laid, that I take
A path thats safe, tho it be farre about,

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: My prayers with heauen guide thee,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Then I will on,
My father is at hand, kisse and begon;
Howres shall be watcht for meetings; I must now
As men for feare, to a strange I doll bow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.L: Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Ile guide thee forth, when next we meete,
A story of Moll shall make our mirth more sweet.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Alexander Wengraue, Sir Dauy Dapper, Sir Adam Appleton, Goshake, Laxton, and Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Thanks good Sir Alexander for our bounteous cheere:

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Fy, fy, in giuing thankes you pay to deare.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dap.
SP.L: When bounty spreades the table, faith t'were sinne,
(at going of) if thankes should not step in.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: No more of thankes, no more, I mary Sir,
Th'inner roome was too close, how do you like
This Parlour Gentlmen?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Oh passing well.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam
SP.L: What a sweet breath the aire casts heere, so coole,

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: I like the prospect best.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: See how tis furnisht.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dap.
SP.L: A very faire sweete roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Sir Dauy Dapper,
The furniture that doth adorne this roome,
Cost many a faire gray groat ere it came here,
But good things are most cheape, when th'are most deere,
Nay when you looke into my galleries,
How brauely they are trim'd vp, you all shall sweare
Yare highly pleasd to see whats set downe there:
Stories of men and women (mixt together
Faire ones with foule, like sun-shine in wet wether)
Within one square a thousand heads are laid
So close, that all of heads, the roome seeemes made,
As many faces there (fill'd with blith lookes)
Shew like the promising titles of new bookes,
(Writ merily) the Readers being their owne eyes,
Which seeme to moue and to giue plaudities,
And here and there (whilst with obsequious eares,
Throng'd heapes do listen) a cut purse thrusts and leeres
With haukes eyes for his prey: I need not shew him,
By a hanging villanous looke, your selues may know him,
The face is drawne so rarely, Then sir below,
The very flowre (as twere) waues to and fro,
And like a floating Iland, seemes to moue,
Vpon a sea bound in with shores aboue,

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: These sights are excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I'le shew you all,
Since we are met, make our parting Comicall.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: This gentleman (my friend) will take his leaue Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Ha, take his leaue (Sebastian) who?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: This gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Your loue sir, has already giuen me some time,
And if you please to trust my age with more,
It shall pay double interest: Good sir stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: I haue beene too bold.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Not so sir. A merry day
Mongst friends being spent, is better then gold sau'd.
Some wine, some wine. Where be these knaues I keepe.
SP.STAGE: Enter three or foure Seruingmen, and Neatfoote.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.L: At your worshipfull elbow, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: You are kissing my maids, drinking, or fast asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.L: Your worship has giuen it vs right.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: You varlets stirre,
Chaires, stooles and cushions: pre'thee sir Dauy Dapper,
Make that chaire thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dap.
SP.L: Tis but an easie gift,
And yet I thanke you for it sir, I'le take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: A chaire for old sir Adam Appleton.

SP.SPEAKER: Neat.
SP.L: A backe friend to your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Mary good Neatfoot,
I thanke thee for it: backe friends sometimes are good.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Pray make that stoole your pearch, good M. Goshawke.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: I stoope to your lure sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Sonne Sebastian,
Take Maister Greenewit to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Sit deere friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Nay maister Laxton—furnish maister Laxton
With what he wants (a stone) a stoole I would say, a stoole.

SP.SPEAKER: Laxton.
SP.L: I had rather stand sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I know you had (good M. Laxton.) So, so—
Now heres a messe of friends, and (gentlemen)
Because times glasse shall not be running long,
I'le quicken it with a pretty tale.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dap.
SP.L: Good tales do well,
In these bad dayes, where vice does so excell.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Begin sir Alexander.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Last day I met
An aged man vpon whose head was scor'd,
A debt of iust so many yeares as these,
Which I owe to my graue, the man you all know.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: His name I pray you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Nay you shall pardon me,
But when he saw me (with a sigh that brake,
Or seem'd to breake his heart-strings) thus he spake:
Oh my good knight, saies he, (and then his eies
Were richer euen by that which made them poore,
They had spent so many teares they had no more.)
Oh sir (saies he) you know it, for you ha seene
Blessings to raine vpon mine house and me:
Fortune (who slaues men) was my slaue: her wheele
Hath spun me golden threads, for I thanke heauen,
I nere had but one cause to curse my starres,
I ask't him then, what that one cause might be.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: So Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: He paus'd, and as we often see,
A sea so much becalm'd, there can be found
No wrinckle on his brow, his waues being drownd
In their owne rage: but when th'imperious wind,
Vse strange inuisible tyranny to shake
Both heauens and earths foundation at their noyse:
The seas swelling with wrath to part that fray
Rise vp, and are more wild, more mad, then they.
Euen so this good old man was by my question
Stir'd vp to roughnesse, you might see his gall
Flow euen in's eies: then grew he fantasticall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dap.
SP.L: Fantasticall, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Yes, and talke odly.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Pray sir proceed,
How did this old man end?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Mary sir thus.
He left his wild fit to read ore his cards,
Yet then (though age cast snow on all his haires)
He ioy'd because (saies he) the God of gold
Has beene to me no niggard: that disease
(Of which all old men sicken) Auarice
Neuer infected me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: He meanes not himselfe i'me sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: For like a lamp,
Fed with continuall oyle, I spend and throw
My light to all that need it, yet haue still
Enough to serue my selfe, oh but (quoth he)
Tho heauens-dew fall, thus on this aged tree,
I haue a sonne thats like a wedge doth cleaue,
My very heart roote,

SP.SPEAKER: S, Dap.
SP.L: Had he such a sonne,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb,
SP.L: Now I do smell a fox strongly.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Lets see: no Maister Greene-wit is not yet
So mellow in yeares as he; but as like Sebastian,
Iust like my sonne Sebastian,—such another.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: How finely like a fencer my father fetches hisby-blowes to hit me, but if I beate you not at your owne weapon of sub∣tilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: This sonne (saith he) that should be
The columne and maine arch vnto my house,
The crutch vnto my age, becomes a whirlewind
Shaking the firme foundation,

SP.SPEAKER: Adam
SP.L: Tis some prodigall.

SP.SPEAKER: Seba.
SP.L: Well shot old Adam Bell.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: No citty monster neither, no prodigall,
But sparing, wary, ciuill, and (tho wiuelesse)
An excellent husband, and such a traueller,
He has more tongues in his head then some haue teeth,

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dap.
SP.L: I haue but two in myne

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: So sparing and so wary,
What then could vex his father so.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Oh a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: A flesh fly, that can vex any man.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: A scuruy woman,
On whom the passionate old man swore he doated:
A creature (saith he) nature hath brought forth
To mocke the sex of woman.—It is a thing
One knowes not how to name, her birth began
Ere she was all made. Tis woman more then man,
Man more then woman, and (which to none can hap)
The Sunne giues her two shadowes to one shape,
Nay more, let this strange thing, walke, stand or sit,
No blazing starre drawes more eyes after it.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dap.
SP.L: A Monster, tis some Monster.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Shee's a varlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Now is my cue to bristle.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: A naughty packe.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Ha boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Whats false, I say shee's nought.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I say that tongue
That dares speake so (but yours) stickes in the throate
Of a ranke villaine, set your selfe aside.—

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: So sir what then.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Any here else had lyed.
I thinke I shall fit you—

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dap.
SP.L: Doth this concerne him.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Ah sirra boy.
Is your bloud heated: boyles it: are you stung,
Ile pierce you deeper yet: oh my deere friends,
I am that wretched father, this that sonne,
That sees his ruine, yet headlong on doth run.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Will you loue such a poyson.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dap.
SP.L: Fye, fye.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Y'are all mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Th'art sicke at heart, yet feelst it not: of all these,
What Gentleman (but thou) knowing his disease
Mortall, would shun the cure: oh Maister Greenewit,
Would you to such an Idoll bow.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: Not I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Heer's Maister Laxton, has he mind to a woman
As thou hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: No not I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Sir I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: There good parts are so rare, there bad so common,
I will haue nought to do with any woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dap.
SP.L: Tis well done Maister Laxton.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Oh thou cruell boy,
Thou wouldst with lust an old mans life destroy,
Because thou seest I'me halfe way in my graue,
Thou shouelst dust vpon me: wod thou mightest haue
Thy wish, most wicked, most vnnaturall.

SP.SPEAKER: Dap.
SP.L: Why sir, tis thought, sir Guy Fitz-Allards daughter
Shall wed your sonne Sebastian.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Sir Dauy Dapper.
I haue vpon my knees, wood this fond boy,
To take that vertuous maiden.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Harke you a word sir.
You on your knees haue curst that vertuous maiden,
And me for louing her, yet do you now
Thus baffle me to my face: were not your knees
In such intreates, giue me Fitz-Allards daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Ile giue thee rats-bane rather.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Well then you know
What dish I meane to feed vpon.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Harke Gentlemen,
He sweares to haue this cut-purse drab, to spite my gall.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Maister Sebastian.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I am deafe to you all.
Ime so bewitcht, so bound to my desires,
Teares, prayers, threats, nothing can quench out those fires
That burne within me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Her bloud shall quench it then,
Loose him not, oh diswade him Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Dap.
SP.L: He shall be weand I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Before his eyes
Lay downe his shame, my griefe, his miseries.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: No more, no more, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I wash a Negro,
Loosing both paines and cost: but take thy flight,
Ile be most neere thee, when I'me least in sight.
Wilde Bucke ile hunt thee breathlesse, thou shalt run on,
But I will turne thee when I'me not thought vpon.
Now sirra what are you, leaue your Apes trickes and speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: A letter from my Captaine to your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Oh, oh, now I remember tis to preferre thee into my seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: To be a shifter vnder your Worships nose of a clean trencher, when ther's a good bit vpon't.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Troth honest fellow—humh—ha—let me see,
This knaue shall be the axe to hew that downe
At which I stumble, has a face that promiseth
Much of a villaine, I will grind his wit,
And if the edge proue fine make vse of it.
Come hither sirra, canst thou be secret, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: As two crafty Atturneys plotting the vndoing of their clyents.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Didst neuer, as thou hast walkt about this towne
Heare of a wench cal'd Moll, mad merry Moll.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Moll cutpurse sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: The same, dost thou know her then,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Aswell as I know twill raine vpon Simon and Iudes day next, I will sift all the tauerns ith citty, and drinke halfe pots with all the Watermen ath bankside, but if you will sir Ile find her out.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: That task is easy, doot then, hold thy hand vp.
Whats this, ist burnt?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: No sir no, a little sindgd with making fire workes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Ther's mony, spend it, that being spent fetch more.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P:
Oh sir that all the poore souldiers in England had
such a leader. For fetching no water Spaniell is like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: This wench we speake of, straies so from her kind
Nature repents she made her. Tis a Mermaid
Has told my sonne to shipwracke.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Ile cut her combe for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Ile tell out gold for thee then: hunt her forth,
Cast out a line hung full of siluer hookes
To catch her to thy company: deepe spendings
May draw her thats most chast to a mans bosome.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: The gingling of Golden bels, and a good foole with a hobbyhorse, wil draw all the whoores ith to wneto dance in a morris,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Or rather, for thats best, (they say sometimes
Shee goes in breeches) follow her as her man.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: And when her breeches are off, shee shall follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Beate all thy braines to serue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Zounds sir, as country wenches beate creame, till butter comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Play thou the suttle spider, weaue fine nets
To insnare her very life.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Her life.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Yes sucke
Her heart-bloud if thou canst, twist thou but cords
To catch her, Ile finde law to hang her vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Spoke like a Worshipfull bencher.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Trace all her steps: at this shee-foxes den
Watch what lambs enter: let me play the sheepeheard
To saue their throats from bleeding, and cut hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: This is the goll shall doot.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Be firme and gaine me
Euer thine owne. This done I entertaine thee:
How is thy name.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: My name sir is Raph Trapdore, honest Raph.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Trapdore, be like thy name, a dangerous step
For her to venture on, but vnto me.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: As fast as your sole to your boote or shooe sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Hence then, be little seene here as thou canst.
Ile still be at thine elbow.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: The trapdores set.
Moll if you budge y'are gon: this me shall crowne,
A Roaring Boy, the Roaring Girle puts downe,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: God a mercy, loose no time.
SP.STAGE: The three shops open in a ranke: the first a Poticaries shop, the next a Fether shop: the third a Sempsters shop: Mistresse Gallipot in tho first, Mistresse Tiltyard in the next, Maister Openworke and his wife in the third, to them enters Laxton, Goshawke and Greenewit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi. Open.
SP.P: Gentlemen what ist you lacke. What ist you buy, see fine bands and ruffes, fine lawnes, fine cambrickes, what ist you lacke Gentlemen, what ist you buy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Yonders the shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Is that shee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Green
SP.L: Shee that minces Tobacco.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: I: shees a Gentlewoman borne I can tell you, tho it be her hard fortune now to shread Indian pot-hearbes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: Oh sir tis many a good womans fortune, when her husband turns bankrout, to begin with pipes and set vp againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: And indeed the raysing of the woman is the lifting vp of the mans head at all times, if one florish, tother will bud as fast I warrant ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Come th'art familiarly acquainted there, I grope that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: And you grope no better ith dark you may chance lye ith ditch when y'are drunke.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Go th'art a misticall letcher.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: I will not deny but my credit may take vp an ounce of pure smoake.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P:
May take vp an ell of pure smock; away go, tis the closest striker. Life I think he cōmits venery 40 foote deepe, no mans aware on't, I like a palpable smockster go to worke so openly, with the tricks of art, that I'me as aparantly seen as a naked boy in a viall, & were it not for a guift of trechery that I haue in me to betray my friend whē he puts most trust in me (masse yonder
hee is too—) and by his iniurie to make good my accesse to her, I should appeare as defectiue in courting, as a Farmers sonne the first day of his feather, that doth nothing at Court, but woe the hangings and glasse windowes for a month toge∣ther, and some broken wayting woman for euer after. I find those imperfections in my venerie, that were't not for flatterie and falshood, I should want discourse and impudence, and hee that wants impudence among women, is worthy to bee kickt out at beds feet.—He shall not see me yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: Troth this is finely shred.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Oh women are the bèst mincers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: 'Thad bin a good phrase for a Cookes wife sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: But 'twill serue generally, like the front of a newe Almanacke; as thus: Calculated for the meridian of Cookes wiues, but generally for all Englishwomen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Nay you shall ha'te sir, I haue fild it for you.
SP.STAGE: Shee puts it to the fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: The pipe's in a good hand, and I wish mine alwaies so.

SP.SPEAKER: Gree.
SP.L: But not to be vs'd a that fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: O pardon me sir, I vnderstand no french.
I pray be couerd. Iacke a pipe of rich smoake.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Rich smoake; that's 6. pence a pipe ist?

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: To me sweet Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Be not forgetful; respect my credit; seem strange;
Art and Wit makes a foole of suspition:—pray be warie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Push, I warrant you:—come, how ist gallants?

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: Pure and excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: I thought 'twas good, you were growne so silent; you are like those that loue not to talke at victuals, tho they make a worse noyse i'the nose then a common fidlers prentice, and discourse a whole Supper with snuffling;—I must speake a word with you anone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Make your way wisely then. (ners,

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Oh what else sir, hee's perfection it selfe, full of man-
But not an acre of ground belonging to 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.P: I and full of forme, h'as ne're a good stoole in's chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: But aboue all religious: hee prayeth daily vpon elder brothers.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.P: And valiant aboue measure; h'as runne three streets from a Serieant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Puh, Puh.
SP.STAGE: he blowes tobacco in their faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Green. Gosh.
SP.L: Oh, puh, ho, ho.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: So, so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Whats the matter now sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: I protest I'me in extreame want of money, if you can supply mee now with any meanes, you doe mee the greatest pleasure, next to the bountie of your loue, as euer poore gen∣tleman tasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: What's the summe would pleasure ye sir?
Tho you deserue nothing lesse at my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Why 'tis but for want of opportunitie thou know'st; I put her off with opportunitie still: by this light I hate her, but for meanes to keepe me in fashion with gallants; for what I take from her, I spend vpon other wenches, beare her in hand still; shee has wit enough to rob her husband, and I waies e∣nough to consume the money: why how now? what the chin-cough?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: Thou hast the cowardliest tricke to come before a mans face and strangle him ere hee be aware, I could find in my heart to make a quarrell in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Poxe and thou do'st, thou know'st I neuer vse to fight with my friends, thou'l but loose thy labour in't. Iacke Dapper!
SP.STAGE: Enter I. Dapper, and his man Gull.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: Mounsier Dapper, I diue downe to your anckles.

SP.SPEAKER: I. Dap.
SP.L: Saue ye gentlemen all three in a peculiar salute.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: He were ill to make a lawyer, hee dispatches three at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: So wel said: but is this of the same Tobacco mistresse Gallipot?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Gal.
SP.L: The same you had at first sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: I wish it no better: this will serue to drinke at my chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Shall we taste a pipe on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Not of this by my troth Gentlemen, I haue sworne before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: What not Iacke dapper.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Pardon me sweet Iacke, I'me sorry I made such a rash oath, but foolish oathes must stand: where art going Iacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.L: Faith to buy one fether.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: One fether, the foole's peculiar still.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.L: Gul.

SP.SPEAKER: Gul.
SP.L: Maister.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.P: Heer's three halfepence for your ordinary, boy, meete me an howre hence in Powles.

SP.SPEAKER: Gul.
SP.P: How three single halfepence; life, this will scarce serue a man in sauce, a halporth of mustard, a halporth of oyle, and a halporth of viniger, whats left then for the pickle herring: this showes like finall beere ith morning after a great surfet of wine ore night, hee could spend his three pound last night in a supper amongst girles and braue baudy-house boyes, I thought his pockets cackeld not for nothing, these are the egs of three pound, Ile go sup'em vp presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Fight, nine, ten Angles, good wench ifaith, and one that loues darkenesse well, she puts out a candle with the best tricks of any drugsters wife in England: but that which mads her I raile vpon oportunity still, and take no notice on't. The other night she would needs lead me into a roome with a can∣dle in her hand to show me a naked picture, where no sooner entred but the candle was sent of an arrant: now I not inten∣ding to vnderstand her, but like a puny at the Innes of venery, cal'd for another light innocently, thus reward I all her cun∣ning with simple mistaking. I know she cosens her husband to keepe me, and Ile keepe her honest, as long as I can, to make the poore man some part of amends, an honest minde of a whooremaister, how thinke you amongst you, what a fresh pipe, draw in a third man.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: No your a horder, you ingrose bith ounces.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.L: Puh I like it not.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Tiltyard
SP.L: What fether ist you'ld haue sir.
These are most worne and most in fashion,
Amongst the Beuer gallants the stone Riders.
The priuate stages audience, the twelu peny stool Gentlemen,
I can enforme you tis the generall fether.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.L: And therefore I mislike it, tell me of generall.
Now a continuall Simon and Iudes raine
Beate all your fethers as flat downe as pancakes.
Shew me——a—spangled fether,

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Tilt.
SP.L: Oh to go a feasting with,
You'd haue it for a hinch boy, you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Masse I had quite forgot,
His Honours footeman was here last night wife,
Ha you done with my Lords shirt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Whats that to you sir,
I was this morning at his Honours lodging,
Ere such a snake as you crept out of your shell.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Oh 'twas well done good wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mt. Op.
SP.L: I hold it better sir, then if you had don't your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma. Op.
SP.P: Nay so say I: but is the Countesses smocke almost donne mouse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi. Op.
SP.L: Here lyes the cambricke sir, but wants I feare mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma. Op.
SP.L: Ile resolue you of that presently,

SP.SPEAKER: Mi. Op.
SP.L: Haida, oh audacious groome,
Dare you presume to noble womens linnen,
Keepe you your yard to measure sheepeheards holland,
I must confine you I see that.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: What say you to this geere.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I dare the arrants critticke in Tobacco
To lay one falt vpon't.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mol in a freese Irkin and a blacke sauegard.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Life yonders Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Mol which Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: honest Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Prithee lets call her—Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Mol, Mol, pist Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: How now, whats the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: A pipe of good tobacco Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I cannot stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Nay Moll puh, prethee harke, but one word ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Well what ist.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: Prithee come hither sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Hart I would giue but too much money to be nibling with that wench, life, sh'as the Spirit of foure great parishes, and a voyce that will drowne all the Citty, me thinkes a braue Captaine might get all his souldiers vpon her, and nere bee beholding to a company of mile-end milke sops, if hee could come on, and come off quicke enough: Such a Moll were a maribone before an Italian, hee would cry bona roba till his ribs were nothing but bone. Ile lay hard siege to her, mony is that Aqua fortis, that eates into many a maidenhead, where the wals are flesh & bloud Ile euer pierce through with a golden auguer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Now thy iudgement Moll, ist not good?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Yes faith tis very good tobacco, how do you sell an an ounce, farewell. God b'y you Mistresse Gallipot,

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Why Mol, Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: I cannot stay now ifaith, I am going to buy a shag uffe, the shop will be shut in presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: Tis the maddest fantasticalst girle:—I neuer knew so much flesh and so much nimblenesse put together.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Shee slips from one company to another, like a fat Eele between a Dutchmās fingers:—Ile watch my time for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Some will not sticke to say shees a man
And some both man and woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: That were excellent, she might first cuckold the hus∣band and then make him do as much for the wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Saue you; how does Mistresse Tiltyard?

SP.SPEAKER: I. Dap.
SP.L: Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Iacke Dappper.

SP.SPEAKER: I. Dap.
SP.L: How dost Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Ile tell the by and by, I go but toth' next shop.

SP.SPEAKER: I. Dap.
SP.L: Thou shalt find me here this howre about a fether.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Nay and a fether hold you in play a whole houre, a goose will last you all the daies of your life. Let me see a good shag ruffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.P: Mistresse Mary that shalt thou ifaith, and the best in the shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: How now, greetings, loue tearmes with a pox betweene you, haue I found out one of your haunts, I send you for hollands, and you're ith the low countries with a mischiefe, I'me seru'd with good ware byth shift, that makes it lye dead so long vpon my hands, I were as good shut vp shop, for when I open it I take nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.P: Nay and you fall a ringing once the diuell can∣not stop you, Ile out of the Belfry as fast as I can—Moll.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Get you from my shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I come to buy. (shop

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Ile sell ye nothing, I warne yee my house and

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: You goody Openworke, you that prick out a poore liuing
And sowes many a bawdy skin-coate together,
Thou priuate pandresse betweene shirt and smock,
I wish thee for a minute but a man:
Thou shouldst neuer vse more shapes, but as th'art
I pitty my reuenge, now my spleenes vp,
SP.STAGE: Enter a fellow with a long rapier by his side.
SP.L: I would not mocke it willingly—ha be thankfull.
Now I forgiue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Mary hang thee, I neuer askt forgiuenesse in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: You goodman swinesface.

SP.SPEAKER: Fellow
SP.L: What wil you murder me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: You remember slaue, how you abusd me t'other night in a Tauerne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fel.
SP.L: Not I by this light.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: No, but by candlelight you did, you haue trickes to saue your oathes, reseruations haue you, and I haue reserued somewhat for you,—as you like that call for more, you know the signe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fel.
SP.P:
Pox ant, had I brought any company along with mee to haue borne witlesse on't, 'twold ne're haue grieu'd me, but to be strucke and nobody by, tis my ill fortune still, why tread vpon a worme they say twill turne taile, but indeed a Gentle∣man
should haue more manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Gallantly performed ifath Mol, and manfully, I loue thee for euer fort, base rogue, had he offerd but the least coun∣ter-buffe, by this hand I was prepared for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: You prepared for him, why should you be prepared for him, was he any more then a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: No nor so much by a yard and a handfull London measure..

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Why do you speake this then, doe you thinke I can∣not ride a stone horse, vnlesse one lead him bith snaffle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Yes and sit him brauely, I know thou canst Mol, twas but an honest mistake through loue, and Ile make amends fort any way, prethee sweete plumpe Mol, when shall thou and I go out a towne together.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Whether to Tyburne prethee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Masse thats out a towne indeed, thou hangst so many iests vpon thy friends stil. I meane honestly to Brainford, Staines or Ware.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: What to do there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Nothing but bee merry and lye together, I'le hire a coach with foure horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: I thought 'twould bee a beastly iourney, you may leaue out one wel, three horses will serue, if I play the iade my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Nay push th'art such another kicking wench, prethee be kind and lets meete.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Tis hard but we shall meete sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Nay but appoint the place then, there's ten Angels in faire gold Mol, you see I do not trifle with you, do but say thou wilt meete me, and Ile haue a coach ready for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Why here's my hand Ile meete you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Oh good gold,—the place sweete Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: It shal be your appointment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Somewhat neere Holborne Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: In Graies-Inne fields then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: A match.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Ile meete you there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: The houre.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Three.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: That will be time enough to sup at Braineford.
SP.STAGE: Fall from them to the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma. Op.
SP.P: I am of such a nature sir, I cannot endure the house when shee scolds, sh'has a tongue will be hard further in a still morning then Saint Antlings-bell, she railes vpon me for for∣raine wenching, that I being a freemā must needs keep a whore ith subburbs, and seeke to impouerish the liberties, when we fall out, I trouble you still to make all whole with my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: No trouble at all, tis a pleasure to mee to ioyne things together.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.P: Go thy waies, I doe this but to try thy honesty Goshawke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.L: How lik'st thou this Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Oh singularly, your fitted now for a bunch, he lookes for all the world with those spangled fethers like a noblemans bedpost: The purity of your wench would I faine try, shee seemes like Kent vnconquered, and I beleeue as many wiles are in her—oh the gallants of these times are shallow let∣chers, they put not their courtship home enough to a wench, tis impossible to know what woman is throughly honest, be∣cause shee's nere thoroughly try'd, I am of that certaine beleefe there are more queanes in this towne of their owne making, then of any mans prouoking, where lyes the slacknesse then? many a poore soule would downe, and ther's nobody will push Women are courted but nere soundly tri'd, (em: As many walke in spurs that neuer ride.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist, Open.
SP.L: Oh abominable.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: Nay more I tell you in priuate, he keeps a whore ith subburbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: O spittle dealing, I came to him a Gentlewo∣man borne. Ile shew you mine armes when you please sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: I had rather see your legs, and begin that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Openworke
SP.P: Tis well knowne he tooke me from a La∣dies seruice, where I was well beloued of the steward, I had my Lattine tongue, and a spice of the French before I came to him, and now doth he keepe a subberbian whoore vnder my nostrils.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: There's waies enough to cry quite with him, harke in thine eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Theres a friend worth a Million.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol
SP.L: I'le try one speare against your chastity Mist. Tiltyard
Though it proue too short by the burgh.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Masse here she is. Enter Ralph Trapdore I'me bound already to serue her, tho it be but a sluttish tricke. Blesse my hopefull yong Mistresse with long life and great limbs, send her the vpper hand of all balifes, and their hungry adherents.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: How now, what art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: A poore ebbing Gentleman, that would gladly wait for the yong floud of your seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: My seruice! what should moue you to offer your ser∣uice to me sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: The loue I beare to your heroicke spirit and mascu∣line womanhood.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: So sir, put case we should retaine you to vs, what parts are there in you for a Gentlewomans seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Of two kinds right Worshipfull: moueable, and immoueable: moueable to run of arrants, and immoueable to stand when you haue occasion to vse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: What strength haue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Strength Mistresse Mol, I haue gon vp into a steeple, and staid the great bell as 'thas beene ringing; stopt a windmill going.
SP.STAGE: Mols trips vp his heels he fals.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: And neuer strucke downe your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Stood as vpright as I do at this present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Come I pardon you for this, it shall bee no disgrace to you: I haue strucke vp the heeles of the high Germaines size ere now,—what not stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: I am of that nature where I loue, I'le bee at my mi∣stresse foot to do her seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Why well said, but say your Mistresse should receiue iniury, haue you the spirit of fighting in you, durst you second her.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P:
Life I haue kept a bridge my selfe, and droue seuen
at a time before me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: But they were all Lincolneshire bullockes by my troth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Well, meete me in Graies-Inne fields, between three and foure this afternoone, and vpon better consideration weele retaine you.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I humbly thanke your good Mistreship,
Ile crack your necke for this kindnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Remember three.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Nay if I faile you hange me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Good wench Ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Whose this.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Tis I Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Prithee tend thy shop and preuent bastards.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Wele haue a pint of the same wine ifaith Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Harke the bell rings, come Gentlemen.
Iacke Dapper where shals all munch.

SP.SPEAKER: Iae. Dap.
SP.L: I am for Parkers ordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Hee's a good guest to'm, hee deserues his boord,
He drawes all the Gentlemen in a terme time thither,
Weele be your followers Iacke, lead the way,
Looke you by my faith the foole has fetherd his nest well.
SP.STAGE: Enter Maister Gallipot, Maister Tiltyard, and seruants with water Spaniels and a ducke.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Tilt.
SP.P: Come shut vp your shops, where's Maister Openworke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Nay aske not me Maister Tiltyard.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Tilt.
SP.L: Wher's his water dog, puh—pist—hur—hur-pist

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Come wenches come, we're going all to Hogs∣den.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: To Hogsden husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: I to Hogsden pigs ny.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: I'me not ready husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Faith thats well—hum—pist—pist.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Come Mistresse Openworke you are so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: I haue no ioy of my life Maister Gallipot.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal,
SP.P: Push, let your boy lead his water Spaniel along, and weele show you the brauest sport at parlous pond, he trug, he trug, he trug, heres the best ducke in England, except my wife, he, he, he, fetch, fetch, fetch, come lets away Of all the yeare this is the sportfulst day.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: If a man haue a free will, where should the vse
More perfect shine then in his will to loue.
All creatures haue their liberty in that,
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Alexander and listens to him.
SP.L: Tho else kept vnder seruile yoke and feare,
The very bondslaue has his freedome there,
Amongst a world of creatures voyc'd and silent.
Must my desires weare fetters—yea are you
So neere, then I must breake with my hearts truth;
Meete griefe at a backe way—well: why suppose.
The two leaud tongues of slander or of truth
Pronounce Mol loathsome: if before my loue
Shee appeare faire, what iniury haue I,
I haue the thing I like? in all things else
Mine owne eye guides me, and I find 'em prosper,
Life what should aile it now? I know that man
Nere truely loues, if he gainesayt he lyes,
That winkes and marries with his fathers eyes.
Ile keepe myne owne wide open.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mol and a porter with a viallon his backe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Here's braue wilfulnesse,
A made match, here she comes, they met a purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.P: Must I carry this great fiddle to your chamber Mistresse Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Fiddle goodman hog-rubber, some of these porters beare so much for others, they haue no time to carry wit for themselues.

SP.SPEAKER: Por.
SP.L: To your owne chamber Mistresse Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P:
Who'le heare an Asse speake: whither else good∣man
pagent-bearer: the're people of the worst memories.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: Why 'twere too great a burthen loue, to haue them carry things in their minds, and a'ther backes together.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Pardon me sir, I thought not you so neere.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: So, so, so.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I would be neerer to thee, and in that fashion,
That makes the best part of all creatures honest.
No otherwise I wish it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Sir I am so poore to requite you, you must looke for nothing but thankes of me, I haue no humor to marry, I loue to lye aboth sides ath bed my selfe; and againe ath' other side, a wife you know ought to be obedient, but I feare me I am too headstrong to obey, therefore Ile nere go about it, I loue you so well sir for your good will I'de be loath you should repent your bargaine after, and therefore weele nere come together at first, I haue the head now of my selfe, and am man enough for a woman, marriage is but a chopping and changing, where a maiden looses one head, and has a worse ith place.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: The most comfortablest answer from a Roaring Girle, that euer mine eares drunke in.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: This were enough now to affright a foole for euer from thee, when tis the musicke that I loue thee for,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: There's a boy spoyles all againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Beleeue it sir I am not of that disdainefull temper, but
I could loue you faithfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: A pox on you for that word. I like you not now,
Y'are a cunning roarer I see that already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: But sleepe vpon this once more sir, you may chance shift a minde to morrow, be not too hasty to wrong your selfe, neuer while you liue sir take a wife running, many haue run out at heeles that haue don't: you see sir I speake against my selfe, and if euery woman would deale with their suter so honestly, poore yonger brothers would not bee so often gul'd with old cosoning widdowes, that turne ore all their wealth in trust to some kinsman, and make the poore Gentleman worke hard for a pension, fare you well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Nay prethee one word more.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: How do I wrong this girle, she puts him of still.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Thinke vpon this in cold bloud sir, you make as much hast as if you were a going vpon a sturgion voyage, take deliberation sir, neuer chuse a wife as if you were going to Virginia.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: And so we parted, my too cursed fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: She is but cunning, giues him longer time in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor
SP.L: Mistresse Mol, Mistresse Mol: so ho ho so ho.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: There boy, there boy, what dost thou go a hawking after me with a red clout on thy finger.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor
SP.P: I forgot to take measure on you for your new bree∣ches.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Hoyda breeches, what will he marry a monster with two trinckets, what age is this? if the wife go in breeches, the man must weare long coates like a foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: What fidlings heere, would not the old patterne haue seru'd your turne.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor.
SP.P: You change the fashion, you say you'le haue the great Dutch slop Mistresse Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Why sir I say so still.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor.
SP.L: Your breeches then will take vp a yard more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Well pray looke it be put in then.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor.
SP.L: It shall stand round and full I warrant you,

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Pray make em easy enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor.
SP.P: I know my fault now, t'other was somewhat stiffe betweene the legges, Ile make these open enough I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Heer's good geere towards, I haue brought vp my sonne to marry a Dutch slop,. and a French dublet, a codpice daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor.
SP.L: So, I haue gone as farre as I can go.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Why then farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor.
SP.P: If you go presently to your chamber Mistresse Ma∣ry, pray send me the measure of your thigh, by some honest body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Well sir, Ile send it by a Porter persently.

SP.SPEAKER: Taylor.
SP.P: So you had neede, it is a lusty one, both of them would make any porters backe ake in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I haue examined the best part of man,
Reason and iudgement, and in loue they tell me,
They leaue me vncontrould, he that is swayd
By an vnfeeling bloud, past heat of loue
His spring time must needes erre, his watch nere goes right
That sets his dyall by a rusty clocke,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: So, and which is that rusty clocke sir you.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: The clocke at Ludgate sir, it nere goes true.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: But thou goest falser: not thy fathers cares
Can keepe thee right, when that insensible worke,
Obayes the workemans art, lets off the houre
And stops againe when time is satisfied,
But thou runst on, and iudgement, thy maine wheele,
Beats by all stoppes, as if the worke would breake
Begunne with long paines for a minutes ruine,
Much like a suffering man brought vp with care.
At last bequeath'd to shame and a short prayer,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I tast you bitterer then I can deserue sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Who has bewitch thee sonne, what diuell or drug,
Hath wrought vpon the weaknesse of thy bloud,
And betrayd all her hopes to ruinous folly?
Oh wake from drowsy and enchanted shame,
Wherein thy soule sits with a golden dreame
Flatred and poysoned, I am old my sonne, (mine owne
Oh let me preuaile quickly, for I haue waightier businesse of
Then to chide thee: I must not to my graue,
As a drunkard to his bed, whereon he lyes
Onely to sleepe, and neuer cares to rise,
Let me dispatch in time, come no more neere her.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Not honestly, not in the way of marriage,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: What sayst thou marriage, in what place, the Sessions house, and who shall giue the bride, prethe, an indite∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Sir now yee take part with the world to wrong her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Why, wouldst thou faine marry to be pointed at,
Alas the numbers great, do not o're burden't,
Why as good marry a beacon on a hill,
Which all the country fixe their eyes vpon
As her thy folly doates on. If thou longst
To haue the story of thy infamous fortunes,
Serue for discourse in ordinaries and tauernes
Th'art in the way: or to confound thy name,
Keepe on, thou canst not misse it: or to strike
Thy wretched father to vntimely coldnesse,
Keepe the left hand still, it will bring thee to't.
Yet if no teares wrung from thy fathers eyes,
Nor sighes that flye in sparkles, from his sorrowes,
Had power to alter what is wilfull in thee,
Me thinkes her very name should fright thee from her,
And neuer trouble me.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Why is the name of Mol so fatall sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Many one sir, where suspect is entred,
For seeke all London from one end to t'other,
More whoores of that name, then of any ten other.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Whats that to her? let those blush for themselues.
Can any guilt in others condemne her?
I'ue vowd to loue her: let all stormes oppose me,
That euer beate against the brest of man,
Nothing but deaths blacke tempest shall diuide vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Oh folly that can dote on nought but shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Put case a wanton itch runs through one name
More then another, is that name the worse,
Where honesty sits possest in't? it should rather
Appeare more excellent, and deserue more praise,
When through foule mists a brightnesse it can raise.
Why there are of the diuels, honest Gentlemen,
And well descended, keepe an open house,
And some ath (good mans) that are arrant knaues.
He hates vnworthily, that by rote contemnes,
For the name neither saues, nor yet condemnes,
And for her honesty, I haue made such proofe an't,
In seuerall formes, so neerely watcht her waies,
I will maintaine that strict, against an army,
Excepting you my father: here's her worst,
Sh'has a bold spirit that mingles with mankind,
But nothing else comes neere it: and oftentimes
Through her apparell somewhat shames her birth,
But she is loose in nothing but in mirth,
Would all Mols were no worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: This way I toyle in vaine and giue but ayme
To infamy and ruine: he will fall,
My blessing cannot stay him: all my ioyes
Stand at the brinke of a deuouring floud
And will be wilfully swallowed: wilfully.
But why so vaine, let all these teares be lost,
Ile pursue her to shame, and so al's crost.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Hee is gon with some strange purpose, whose effect
Will hurt me little if he shoot so wide,
To thinke I loue so blindly: I but feed
His heart to this match, to draw on th'other.
Wherein my ioy sits with a full wish crownd;
Onely his moode excepted which must change.
By opposite pollicies, courses indirect,
Plaine dealing in this world takes no effect.
This madde girle I'le acquaint with my intent,
Get her assistance, make my fortunes knowne,
Twixt louers hearts, shee's a fit instrument,
And has the art to help them to their owne,
By her aduise, for in that craft shee's wise,
My loue and I may meete, spite of all spies.
SP.STAGE: Enter Laxton in Graies-Inne fields with the Coachman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Coachman.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.L: Heere sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: There's a tester more, prethee driue thy coach to the hither end of Marybone parke, a fit place for Mol to get in.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.L: Marybone parke fir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I, its in our way thou knowst.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.L: It shall be done fir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Coachman.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.L: A non sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Are we fitted with good phrampell iades.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.L: The best in Smithfield I warrant your sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: May we safely take the vpper hand of any coacht vel∣uet cappe or tuftaffety iacket, for they keepe a vilde swag∣gering in coaches now a daies, the hye waies are stopt with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.P: My life for yours and baffle em to sir,—why they are the same iades beleeue it sir, that haue drawne all your fa∣mous whores to Ware.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Nay then they know their businesse, they neede no more instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.P: The're so vsd to such iourneis sir, I neuer vse whip to em; for if they catch but the sent of a wench once, they runne like diuels.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Fine Cerberus, that rogue will haue the start of a thousand ones, for whilst others trot a foot, heele ride praun∣cing to hell vpon a coach-horse.

Stay, tis now about the hourse of her appointment, but yet I see her not, harke whats this, one, two three, three by the clock The clocke striks three. at Sauoy, this is the houre, and Graies-Inne fields the place, shee swore she'ed meete mee: ha yonders two Innes a Court∣men with one wench, but thats not shee, they walke toward Islington out of my way, I see none yet drest like her, I must looke for a shag ruffe, a freeze ierken, a shortsword, and a safeguard, or I get none: why Mol prethee make hast, or the Coachman will cursse vs anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P:
Oh heeres my Gentleman: if they would keepe their daies as well with their Mercers as their houres with their harlots, no bankrout would giue seuen score pound for a seriants place, for would you know a catchpoole rightly deri∣riu'd,
the corruption of a Cittizen, is the generation of a ser∣iant, how his eye hawkes for venery. Come are you ready sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Ready, for what sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Do you aske that now sir, why was this meeting pointed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I thought you mistooke me sir,
You seeme to be some yong barrister,
I haue no suite in law—all my land's sold
I praise heauen for't; t'has rid me of much trouble,

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Then I must wake you sir, where stands the coach,

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Whose this, Mol: honest Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: So young, and purblind, your an old wanton in your eyes I see that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Th'art admirably suited for the three pigions at Brainford, Ile sweare I knew thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Ile sweare you did not: but you shall know me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: No not here, we shall be spyde efaith, the coach is bet∣ter, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: What wilt thou vntrusse a point Mol.
SP.STAGE: Shee puts of her cloake and drawes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Yes, heere's the point that I vntrusse, 'thas but one tag, 'twill serue tho to tye vp a rogues tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: How. (here's her pace,

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: There's the gold with which you hir'd your hackney,
Shee rackes hard, and perhaps your bones will feele it,
Ten angels of mine own, I'ue put to thine, win em, & weare em,

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Hold Moll, Mistresse Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Draw or Ile serue an execution on thee
Shall lay thee vp till doomes day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Draw vpon a woman, why what dost meane Mol?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: To teach thy base thoughts manners: th'art one of those
That thinkes each woman thy fond flexable whore,
If she but cast a liberall eye vpon thee,
Turne backe her head, shees thine, or amongst company,
By chance drinke first to thee: then shee's quite gon,
There's no meanes to help her: nay for a need,
Wilt sweare vnto thy credulous fellow letchers.
That th'art more in fauour with a Lady at first sight
Then her monky all her life time,
How many of our sex, by such as thou
Haue their good thoughts paid with a blasted name
That neuer deserued loosly or did trip
In path of whooredome, beyond cup and lip.
But for the staine of conscience and of soule,
Better had women fall into the hands
Of an act silent, then a bragging nothing,
There's no mercy in't—what durst moue you sir,
To think me whoorish? a name which Ide teare out
From the hye Germaines throat, if it lay ledger there
To dispatch priuy slanders against mee.
In thee I defye all men, there worst hates,
And their best flatteries, all their golden witchcrafts,
With which they intangle the poore spirits of fooles,
Distressed needlewomen and trade-fallne wiues.
Fish that must needs bite, or themselues be bitten,
Such hungry things as these may soone be tooke
With a worme fastned on a golden hooke.
Those are the letchers food, his prey, he watches
For quarrelling wedlockes, and poore shifting sisters,
Tis the best fish he takes: but why good fisherman,
Am I thought meate for you, that neuer yet
Had angling rod cast towards me? cause youl'e say
I'me giuen to sport, I'me often mery, iest,
Had mirth no kindred in the world but lust?
O shame take all her friends then: but how ere
Thou and the baser world censure my life,
Ile send 'em word by thee, and write so much
Vpon thy breast, cause thou shalt bear't in mind,
Tell them 'twere base to yeeld, where I haue conquer'd.
I scorne to prostitute my selfe to a man,
I that can prostitue a man to mee,
And so I greete thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Would the spirits of al my slanders, were claspt in thine.
That I might vexe an army at one time,

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I do repent me, hold,

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: You'l die the better Christian then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I do confesse I haue wrong'd thee Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Confession is but poore amends for wrong,
Vnlesse a rope would follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I aske thee pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I'me your hir'd whoore fir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I yeeld both purse and body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Both are mine, and now at my disposing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Spare my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I scorne to strike thee basely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Spoke like a noble girle i'faith.
SP.P: Heart I thinke I fight with a familiar, or the Ghost of a fencer, Sh'has wounded me gallantly, call you this a letcherous viage? Here's bloud would haue seru'd me this seuen yeare in broken heads and cut fingers, & it now runs all out together, pox athe three pigions, I would the coach were here now to carry mee to the Chirurgions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: If I could meete my enemies one by one thus,
I might make pretty shift with 'em in time,
And make 'em know, shee that has wit, and spirit,
May scorne to liue beholding to her body for meate,
Or for apparell like your common dame,
That makes shame get her cloathes, to couer shame.
Base is that minde, that kneels vnto her body,
As if a husband stood in awe on's wife,
My spirit shall be Mistresse of this house,
As long as I haue time in't.——oh
Heere comes my man that would be: 'tis his houre.
Faith a good well set fellow, if his spirit
Be answerable to his vmbles; he walkes stiffe,
But whether he will stand to't stifly, there's the point;
Has a good calfe for't, and ye shall haue many a woman
Choose him shee meanes to meke her head, by his calfe;
I do not know their trickes in't, faith he seemes
A man without; I'le try what he is within,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Shee told me Gries-Inne fields twixt three & foure,
Ile fit her Mistreship with a peece of seruice,
I'me hir'd to rid the towne of one mad girle.
What a pox ailes you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: He beginnes like a Gentleman,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Heart, is the field so narrow, or your eye-sight:
Life he comes backe againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Was this spoke to me sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I cannot tell sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Go y'are a coxcombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Coxcombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Y'are a slaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I hope there's law for you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Ye, do you see sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Heart this is no good dealing, pray let me know what house your off.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: One of the Temple sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Masse so me thinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: And yet sometime I lye about chicke lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I like you the worse because you shift your lodging▪
Ile not meddle with you for that tricke sir. (so often

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: A good shift, but it shall not serue your turne.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: You'le giue me leaue to passe about my businesse sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Your businesse, Ile make you waite on mee before I ha done, and glad to serue me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: How sir, serue you, not if there were no more men in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: But if there were no more women in England
I hope you'd waite vpon your Mistresse then,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Oh your a tri'd spirit at a push sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: What would your Worship haue me do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: You a fighter.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: No, I praise heauen, I had better grace & more maners.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: As how I pray sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P:
Life, 'thad bene a beastly part of me to haue drawne my weapons vpon my Mistresse, all the world would a cry'd
shame of me for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Why but you knew me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Do not say so Mistresse, I knew you by your wide straddle, as well as if I had bene in your belly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Well, we shall try you further, ith meane time wee giue you intertainement.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Thanke your good Mistreship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: How many suites haue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: No more suites then backes Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Well if you deserue, I cast of this, next weeke,
And you may creepe into't.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Thanke your good Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Come follow me to S. Thomas Apostles,
Ile put a liuery cloake vpon your backe, the first thing I do,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I follow my deere Mistresse.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mistresse Gallipot as from supper, her husband after her.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: What Pru, Nay sweete Prudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: What a pruing keepe you, I thinke the baby would haue a teate it kyes so, pray be not so fond of me, leaue your Citty humours, I'me vext at you to see how like a calfe you come bleating after me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Nay hony Pru: how does your rising vp before all the table shew? and flinging from my friends so vnciuily, fiye Pru, fye, come.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Then vp and ride ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Vp and ride, nay my pretty Pru, thats farre from my thought, ducke: why mouse, thy minde is nibbling at something, whats ist, what lyes vpon thy Stomach?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Such an asse as you: hoyda, y'are best turne mid∣wife, or Physition: y'are a Poticary already, but I'me none of your drugs.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Thou art a sweete drug, sweetest Pru, and the more thou art pounded, the more pretious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Must you be prying into a womans secrets: say ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Womans secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: What? I cannot haue a qualme come vpon mee but your teeth waters, till your nose hang ouer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: It is my loue deere wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Your loue? your loue is all words; giue mee deeds, I cannot abide a man thats too fond ouerme, so coo∣kish; thou dost not know how to handle a woman in her kind,

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: No Pru? why I hope I haue handled.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Handle a fooles head of your owne,—fih—fih.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, tis such a waspe; it does mee good now to haue her sing me, little rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Now fye how you vex me, I cannot abide these aperne husbands: such cotqueanes, you ouerdoe your things, they become you scuruily.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Vpon my life she breeds, heauen knowes how I haue straind my selfe to please her, night and day: I wonder why wee Cittizens should get children so fretfull and vnto∣ward in the breeding, their fathers being for the most part as gentle as milch kine: shall I leaue thee my Pru.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Fye, fye, fye.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Thou shalt not bee vext no more, pretty kind rogue, take no cold sweete Pru.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: As your wit has done: now Maister Laxton shew your head, what newes from you? would any husband suspect that a woman crying, Buy any scurui-grasse, should bring loue letters amongst her herbes to his wife, pretty tricke, fine con∣ueyance? had iealousy a thousand eyes, a silly woman with scur∣uy-grasse blinds them all; Laxton with bayes crown I thy wit for this, it deserues praise.
SP.L: This makes me affect thee more, this prooues thee wise,
Lacke what poore shift is loue forc't to deuise? (toth' point)
SP.STAGE:
She reads the letter. O Sweete Creature—(a sweete beginning) pardon my long ab∣sence, for thou shalt shortly be possessed with my presence; though Demophon was false to Phillis, I will be to thee as Pan-da-rus was to Cres-sida: tho Eneus made an asse of Dido, I will dye to thee ere I do so; o sweetest creature make much of me, for no man
beneath the siluer moone shall make more of a woman then I do of thee, furnish me therefore with thirty pounds, you must doe it of necessity for me; I languish till I see some comfort come from thee, protesting not to dye in thy debt, but rather to liue so, as hitherto I haue and will. Thy true Laxton euer.
SP.L: Alas poore Gentleman, troth I pitty him,
How shall I raise this money? thirty pound?
Tis thirty sure, a 3 before an 0,
I know his threes too well; my childbed linnen?
Shall I pawne that for him? then if my marke
Be knowne I am vndone; it may be thought
My husband's bankrout: which way shall I turne?
Laxton, what with my owne feares, and thy wants,
I'me needle twixt two adamants.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Nay, nay, wife, the women are all vp, ha, how, reading a letters? I smel a goose, a couple of capons, and a gam∣mon of bacon from her mother out of the country, I hold my life,—steale,—steale.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: O beshrow your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: What letter's that? I'le see't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Oh would thou had'st no eyes to see the downefall of me and thy selfe: I'me for euer, for euer I'me vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: What ailes my Pru? what paper's that thou tear'st?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Would I could teare
My very heart in peeces: for my soule
Lies on the racke of shame, that tortures me
Beyond a womans suffering.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gall:
SP.L: What meanes this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Had you no other vengeance to throw downe,
But euen in heigth of all my ioyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Deere woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: When the full sea of pleasure and content seem'd to flow ouer me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P:
As thou desirest to keepe mee out of bedlam,
tell what troubles thee, is not thy child at nurse falne sicke, or dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Oh no.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Heauens blesse me, are my barnes and houses
Yonder at Hockly hole consum'd with fire,
I can build more, sweete Pru.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Tis worse, tis worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: My factor broke, or is the Ionas suncke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Would all we had were swallowed in the waues,
Rather then both should be the scorne of slaues.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: I'me at my wits end.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Oh my deere husband,
Where once I thought my selfe a fixed starre,
Plac't onely in the heauen of thine armes,
I feare now I shall proue a wanderer,
Oh Laxton, Laxton, is it then my fate
To be by thee orethrowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Defend me wisedome,
From falling into frenzie, on my knees. (thy bosome.
Sweete Pru, speake, whats that Laxton who so heauy lyes on

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: I shall sure run mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: I shall run mad for company then: speak to me,
I'me Gallipot thy husband,—Pru,—why Pru.
Art sicke in conscience for some villanous deed
Thou wert about to act, didst meane to rob me,
Tush I forgiue thee, hast thou on my bed
Thrust my soft pillow vnder anothers head?
Ile winke at all faults Pru, las thats no more,
Then what some neighbours neere thee, haue done before,
Sweete hony Pru, whats that Laxton?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Oh.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Out with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Oh hee's borne to be my vndoer,
This hand which thou calst thine, to him was giuen,
To him was I made sure ith sight of heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: I neuer heard this thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Yes, yes, before
I was to thee contracted, to him I swore,
Since last I saw him twelue moneths three times told,
The Moone hath drawne through her light siluer bow,
For ore the seas hee went, and it was said,
(But Rumor lyes) that he in France was dead.
But hee's aliue, oh hee's aliue, he sent,
That letter to me, which in rage I rent,
Swearing with oathes most damnably to haue me,
Or teare me from this bosome, oh heauens saue me,

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: My heart will breake,—sham'd and vndone for euer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: So black a day (poore wretch) went ore thee neuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: If thou shouldst wrastle with him at the law,
Th'art sure to fall, no odde slight, no preuention.
Ile tell him th'art with child.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Vmh.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gall.
SP.P: Or giue out one of my men was tane a bed with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Vmh, vmh.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Before I loose thee my deere Pru;
Ile driue it to that push.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Worse, and worse still,
You embrace a mischiefe, to preuent an ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Ile buy thee of him, stop his mouth with Gold,
Think'st thou twill do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Oh me, heauens grant it would,
Yet now my sences are set more in tune,
He writ, as I remember in his letter,
That he in riding vp and downe had spent,
(Ere hee could finde me) thirty pounds, send that,
Stand not on thirty with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Forty Pru, say thou the word tis done, wee venture liues for wealth, but must do more to keepe our wiues, thirty or forty Pru.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Thirty good sweete
Of an ill bargaine lets saue what we can,
Ile pay it him with my teares, he was a man
When first I knew him of a meeke spirit,
All goodnesse is not yet dryd vp I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gall.
SP.L: He shall haue thirty pound, let that stop all:
Loues sweets tast best, when we haue drunke downe Gall.
SP.STAGE: Enter Maister Tiltyard, and his wife, Maister Goshawke, and Mistresse Openworke.
SP.L: Gods so, our friends; come, come, smoth your cheeke;
After a storme the face of heauen looks sleeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Tilt.
SP.L: Did I not tell you these turtles were together?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Tilt.
SP.L: How dost thou sirra? why sister Gallipot?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Lord how shee's chang'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Is your wife ill sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Yes indeed la sir, very ill, very ill, neuer worse,

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Tilt.
SP.L: How her head burnes, feele how her pulses work.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Sister lie downe a little, that alwaies does mee good.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Tilt.
SP.L: In good sadnesse I finde best ease in that too,
Has shee laid some hot thing to her Stomach?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: No, but I will lay something anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Tilt.
SP.P: Come, come fooles, you trouble her, shal's goe Maister Goshawke?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: Yes sweete Maister Tiltyard; sirra Rosamond I hold my life Gallipot hath vext his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Shee has a horrible high colour indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: Wee shall haue your face painted with the same red soone at night, when your husband comes from his rubbers in a false alley; thou wilt not beleeue me that his bowles run with a wrong byas.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: It cannot sinke into mee, that hee feedes vpon stale mutten abroad, hauing better and fresher at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: What if I bring thee, where thou shalt see him stand at racke and manger?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Ile saddle him in's kind, and spurre him till hee kicke againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Shall thou and I ride our iourney then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Heere's my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: No more; come Maister Tiltyard, shall we leape into the stirrops with our women, and amble home?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Tilt.
SP.L: Yes, yes, come wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Tilt.
SP.L: Introth sister, I hope you will do well for all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: I hope I shall: farewell good sister: sweet Maister Goshawke.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Welcome brother, most kindlie welcome sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Thankes sir for our good cheere.
SP.STAGE: Exeunt all but Gallipot and his wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: It shall be so, because a crafty knaue
Shall not out reach me, nor walke by my dore
With my wife arme in arme, as 'twere his whoore,
I'le giue him a golden coxcombe, thirty pound:
Tush Pru what's thirty pound? sweete ducke looke cheerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
