SP.L: Thou art worthy of my heart thou bui'st it deerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: Vds light the tide's against me, a pox of your Potti∣carishp: oh for some glister to set him going; 'tis one of Her∣cules labours, to tread one of these Cittie hennes, because their cockes are stil crowing ouer them; there's no turning tale here, I must on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Oh, husband see he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Let me deale with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Blesse you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Be you blest too sir if you come in peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Haue you any good pudding Tobacco sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Oh picke no quarrels gentle sir, my husband
Is not a man of weapon, as you are,
He knowes all, I haue opned all before him, concerning you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Zounes has she showne my letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist Gal.
SP.L: Suppose my case were yours, what would you do.
At such a pinch, such batteries, such assaultes▪
O father, mother, kinred, to dissolue
The knot you tyed, and to be bound to him?
How could you shift this storme off?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: If I know hang me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Besides a story of your death was read
Each minute to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: What a pox meanes this ridling?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Be wise sir, let not you and I be tost
On Lawiers pens; they haue sharpe nibs and draw
Mens very heart bloud from them; what need you sir
To beate the drumme of my wifes infamy,
And call your friends together sir to prooue
Your precontact, when sh'has confest it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Vmh sir,—has she confest it?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Sh'has 'faith to me sir, vpon your letter sending.

SP.SPEAKER: M. ist. Gal.
SP.L: I haue, I haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: If I let this yron coole call me slaue,
Do you heare, you dame Prudence? think'st thou vile woman
I'le take these blowes and winke?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Vpon my knees.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Out impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: You goatish slaues,
No wilde foule to cut vp but mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Alas sir,
You make her flesh to tremble, frighr her not,
Shee shall do reason, and what's fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I'le haue thee, wert thou more common
Then an hospitall, and more diseased.—

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: But one word good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: So sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: I married her, haue line with her, and goy
Two children on her body, thinke but on that;
Haue you so beggarly an appetite
When I vpon a dainty dish haue fed
To dine vpon my scraps, my leauings? ha sir?
Do I come neere you uow sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Be Lady you touch me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Would not you scorne to weare my cloathes sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Right sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Then pray sir weare not her, for shee's a garment
So fitting for my body, I'me loath
Another should put it on, you will vndoe both.
Your letter (as shee said) complained you had spent
In quest of her, some thirty pound, I'le pay it;
Shall that sir stop this gap vp twixt you two?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Well if I swallow this wrong, let her thanke you:
The mony being paid sir, I am gon:
Farewell, oh women happy's hee trusts none.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Dispatch him hence sweete husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Yes deere wife: pray sir come in, ere Maister
Thou shalt in wine drinke to him,
SP.STAGE: Exit Maister Gallipot and his wife. (Laxton part

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: With all my heart;—how dost thou like my wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Rarely, that wile
By which the Serpent did the first woman beguile,
Did euer since, all womens bosomes fill;
Y'are apple eaters all, deceiuers still.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Alexander Wengraue: Sir Dauy Dapper, Sir Adam Appleton, at one dore, and Trapdore at another doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Out with your tale Sir Dauy, to Sir Adam.
A Knaue is in mine eie deepe in my debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Da.
SP.L: Nay: if hee be a knaue sir, hold him fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Speake softly, what egge is there hatching now.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: A Ducks egge sir, a ducke that has eaten a frog, I haue crackt the shell, and some villany or other will peep out presently; the ducke that sits is the bouncing Rampe (that Roaring Girle my Mistresse) the drake that must tread is your sonne Sebastian.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Be quicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: As the tongue of an oister wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: And see thy newes be true.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: As a barbars euery satterday night—mad Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Ah.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Must be let in without knocking at your backe gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: So.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Your chamber will be made baudy.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Good.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Shee comes in a shirt of male.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: How shirt of male?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Yes sir or a male shirt, that's to say in mans apparell.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: To my sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Close to your sonne: your sonne and her Moone will be in coniunction, if all Alminacks lie not, her blacke saueguard is turned into a deepe sloppe, the holes of her vpper body to button holes, her wastcoate to a dublet, her placket to the ancient seate of a codpice, and you shall take 'em both with standing collers.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Art sure of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: As euery throng is sure of a pick-pocket, as sure as a whoore is of the clyents all Michaelmas Tearme, and of the pox after the Tearme.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: The time of their tilting?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Three.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: The day?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: This.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Away ply it, watch her.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: As the diuell doth for the death of a baud, I'le watch her, do you catch her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Shee's fast: heere weaue thou the nets; harke,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: They are made. (maintain't.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I told them thou didst owe mee money; hold it vp:

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Stifly; as a Puritan does contention,
Foxe I owe thee not the value of a halfepenny halter.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Thou shalt be hang'd in't ere thou scape so.
Varlet I'le make thee looke through a grate.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: I'le do'tpresently, through a Tauerne grate, drawer: pish.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Has the knaue vext you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Askt him my mony,
He sweares my sonne receiu'd it: oh that boy
Will nere leaue heaping sorrowes on my heart,
Till he has broke it quite.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Is he still wild?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: As is a russian Beare.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: But he has left
His old haunt with that baggage.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Worse still and worse,
He laies on me his shame, I on him my curse.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: My sonne Iacke Dapper then shall run with him,
All in one pasture.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Proues your sonne bad too sir?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: As villany can make him: your Sebastian
Doares but on one drabb, mine on a thousand,
A noyse of fiddlers, Tobacco, wine and a whoore,
A Mercer that will let him take vp more,
Dyce, and a water spaniell with a Ducke: oh,
Bring him a bed with these, when his purse gingles,
Roaring boyes follow at's tale, fencers and ningles,
(Beasts Adam nere gaue name to) these horse-leeches sucke
My sonne, he being drawne dry, they all liue on smoake.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Tobacco?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy
SP.L: Right, but I haue in my braine
A windmill going that shall grind to dust
The follies of my sonne, and make him wise,
Or a starke foole; pray lend me your aduise.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: That shall you good sir Dauy.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: Heere's the sprindge
Iha set to catch this woodcocke in: an action
In a false name (vnknowne to him) is entred.
I'th Counter to arrest Iacke Dapper.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Ha, ha, he.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: Thinke you the Counter cannot breake him?

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Breake him?
Yes and brēake's heart too if he lie there long.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: I'le make him sing a Counter tenor sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: No way to tame him like it, there hee shall learne
What mony is indeed, and how to spend it.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: Hee's bridled there.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I, yet knowes not how to mend it,
Bedlam cures not more madmen in a yeare,
Then one of the Counters does, men pay more deere
There for there wit then any where; a Counter
Why 'tis an vniuersity, who not sees?
As schollers there, so heere men take degrees,
And follow the same studies (all alike.)
Schollers learne first Logicke and Rhetoricke.
So does a prisoner; with fine honied speech
At's first comming in he doth perswade, beseech,
He may be lodg'd with one that is not itchy;
To lie in a cleane chamber, in sheets not lowsy,
But when he has no money, then does he try,
By subtile Logicke, and quaint sophistry,
To make the keepers trust him.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Say they do.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Then hee's a graduate.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: Say they trust him not,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Then is he held a freshman and a sot,
And neuer shall commence, but being still bar'd
Be expulst from the Maisters side, toth' twopenny ward,
Or else i'th hole, beg plac't.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: When then I pray proceeds a prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: When mony being the theame,
He can dispute with his hard creditors hearts,
And get out cleere, hee's then a Maister of Arts;
Sir Dauy send your sonne to Woodstreet Colledge,
A Gentleman can no where get more knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: There Gallants study hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: True: to get mony.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: 'lies bith' heeles i'faith, thankes, thankes, I ha sent
For a couple of beares shall paw him.
SP.STAGE: Enter Seriant Curtilax and Yeoman Hanger.

SP.SPEAKER: Adam.
SP.L: Who comes yonder?

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: They looke like puttocks, these should be they.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I know 'em, they are officers, sir wee'l leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: My good knights.
Leaue me, you see I'me haunted now with spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Fare you well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: This old muzzle chops should be he
By the fellowes discription: Saue you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.P: Come hither you mad varlets, did not my man tell you I watcht here for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: One in a blew coate sir told vs, that in this place an old Gentleman would watchforvs, a thing contrary to our oath, for we are to watch for euery wicked member in a Citty.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.P: You'l watch then fot ten thousand, what's thy name honesty?

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Seriant Curtilax I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: An excellent name for a Seriant, Curtilax.
Seriants indeed are weapons of the law,
When prodigall ruffians farre in debt are growne,
Should not you cut them; Cittizens were orethrowne,
Thou dwel'st hereby in Holborne Curtilax.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: That's my circuit sir, I coniure most in that circle.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: And what yong toward welp is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Hang.
SP.L: Of the same litter, his yeoman sir, my name's Hanger.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: Yeoman Hanger.
One paire of sheeres sure cut out both your coates,
You haue two names most dangerous to mens throates,
You two are villanous loades on Gentlemens backs,
Deere ware, this Hanger and this Curtilax.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: We are as other men are sir, I cannot see but hee who makes a show of honesty and religion, if his clawes can fa∣sten to his liking, he drawes bloud; all that liue in the world, are but great fish and little fish, and feede vpon one another, some eate vp whole men, a Seriant cares but for the shoulder of a man, they call vs knaues and curres, but many times hee that sets vs on, worries more lambes one yeare, then we do in seuen.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: Spoke like a noble Cerberus, is the action entred?

SP.SPEAKER: Hang.
SP.L: His name is entred in the booke of vnbeleeuers.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: What booke's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: The booke where all prisoners names stand, and not one amongst forty, when he comes in, beleeues to come out in hast.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Da.
SP.L: Be as dogged to him as your office allowes you to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Oh sir.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: You know the vnthrift Iacke Dapper.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: I, I, sir, that Gull? aswell as I know my yeoman.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.L: And you know his father too, Sir Dauy Dapper?

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: As damn'd a vsurer as euer was among Iewes; if hee were sure his fathers skinne would yeeld him any money, hee would when he dyes flea it off, and sell it to couer drummes for children at Bartholmew faire.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.P: What toades are these to spit poyson on a man to his face? doe you see (my honest rascals?) yonder gray-hound is the dog he hunts with, out of that Tauerne Iacke Dapper will sally sa, sa; giue the counter, on, set vpon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Wee'l charge him vppo'th backe sir.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.P: Take no baile, put mace enough into his caudle, double your files, trauerse your ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Braue sir.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy:
SP.L: Cry arme, arme, arme.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Thus sir.

SP.SPEAKER: S. Dauy.
SP.P: There boy, there boy, away: looke to your prey my trew English wolues, and and so I vanish.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: Some warden of the Seriants begat this old fellow vpon my life, stand close.

SP.SPEAKER: Hang.
SP.L: Shall the ambuscado lie in one place?

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: No uooke thou yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Ralph.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: What sayes my braue Captaine male and female?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: This Holborne is such a wrangling streete,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: That s because Lawiers walkes to and fro in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Heere's such iustling, as if euery one wee met were drunke and reel'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Stand Mistresse do you not smell carrion?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Carryon? no, yet I spy rauens.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Some poore winde-shaken gallant will anon fall into sore labour, and these men-midwiues must bring him to bed i'the counter, there all those that are great with child with debts, lie in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Stand vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Like your new maypoll.

SP.SPEAKER: Hang.
SP.L: Whist, whew.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Hump, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Peeping? it shall go hard huntsmen, but I'le spoyle your game, they looke for all the world like two infected malt∣men comming muffled vp in their cloakes in a frosty morning to London.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: A course, Captaine; a beare comes to the stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: It should bee so, for the dogges struggle to bee let loose.

SP.SPEAKER: Hang.
SP.L: Whew.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.L: Hemp.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Harke Trapdore, follow your leader.

SP.SPEAKER: Iacke Dap.
SP.L: Gul.

SP.SPEAKER: Gul.
SP.L: Maister.

SP.SPEAKER: Iacke Dap.
SP.L: Did'st euer see such an asse as I am boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Gul.
SP.P: No by my troth sir, to loose all your mony, yet haue false dice of your owne, why 'tis as I saw a great fellow vsed t'other day, he had a faire sword and buckler, and yet a butcher dry beate him with a cudgell.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: Honest Serieant fly, flie Maister Dapper you'l be ar∣rested else.

SP.SPEAKER: Iacke Dap.
SP.L: Run Gul and draw.

SP.SPEAKER: Gul.
SP.L: Run Maister, Gull followes you.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: I know you well enough, you'r but a whore to hang vpon any man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Whores then are like Seriants, so now hang you, draw rogue, but strike not: for a broken pate they'l keepe their bds, and recouer twenty markes damages.

SP.SPEAKER: Curt.
SP.P: You shall pay for this rescue, runne downe shoe∣lane and meete him.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Shu, is this a rescue Gentlemen or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Rescue? a pox on 'em, Trapdore let's away,
I'me glad I haue done perfect one good worke to day,
If any Gentleman be in Scriueners bands,
Send but for Mol, she'll baile him by these hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Vnahppy in the follies of a sonne,
Led against iudgement, sence, obedience,
And all the powers of noblenesse and wit;
Oh wretched father, now Trapdore will she come?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: In mans apparell sir, I am in her heart now,
And share in all her secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Peace, peace, peace.
Here take my Germane watch, hang't vp in sight,
That I may see her hang in English for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I warrant you for that now, next Sessions rids her sir,
This watch will bring her in better then a hundred constables.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Good Trapdore saist thou so, thou cheer'st my heart
After a storme of sorrow,—my gold chaine too,
Here take a hundred markes in yellow linkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: That will do well to bring the watch to light sir.
And worth a thousand of your Headborowes lanthornes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Place that a'the Court cubbart, let it lie
Full in the veiw of her theefe-whoorish eie.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Shee cannot misse it sir, I see't so plaine, that I could steal't my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Perhaps thou shalt too,
That or something as weighty; what shee leaues,
Thou shalt come closely in, and filch away,
And all the weight vpon her backe I'le lay.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: You cannot assure that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: No, what lets it?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Being a stout girle, perhaps shee'l desire pressing,
Then all the weight must ly vpon her belly.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Belly or backe I care not so I'ue one.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: You'r of my minde for that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Hang vp my ruffe band with the diamond at it,
It may be shee'l like that best.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: It's well for her, that shee must haue her choice, hee thinkes nothing too good for her, if you hold on this minde a little longer, it shall bee the first worke I doe to turne theefe my selfe; would do a man good to be hang'd when he is so wel prouided for.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: So, well sayd; all haugs well, would shee hung so too,
The sight would please me more, then all their gilsterings:
Oh that my mysteries to such streights should runne,
That I must rob my selfe to blesse my sonne.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sebastian, with Mary Fitz-Allard like a page, and Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Thou hast done me a kind office, without touch
Either of sinne or shame, our loues are honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I'de scorne to make such shift to bring you together else▪

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Now haue I time and opportunity
Without all feare to bid thee welcome loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.L: Neuer with more desire and harder venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: How strange this shewes one man to kisse another.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I'de kisse such men to chuse Moll,
Me thinkes a womans lip tasts well in a dublet:

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Many an old madam has the better fortune then,
Whose breathes grew stale before the fashion came,
If that will help 'em, as you thinke 'twill do,
They'l learne in time to plucke on the hose too.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: The older they waxe Moll, troth I speake seriously,
As some haue a conceit their drinke tasts better
In an outlandish cup then in our owne,
So me thinkes euery kisse she giues me now
In this strange forme, is worth a paire of two,
Here we are safe, and furthest from the eie
Of all suspicion, this is my fathets chamber,
Vpon which floore he neuer steps till night.
Here he mistrusts me not, nor I his comming,
At mine owne chamber he still pries vnto me,
My freedome is not there at mine owne finding,
Still checkt and curb'd, here he shall misse his purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: And what's your businesse now, you haue your mind sir;
At your great suite I promisd you to come,
I pittied her for names sake, that a Moll
Should be so crost in loue, when there's so many,
That owes nine layes a peece, and not so little:
My taylor fitted her, how like you his worke?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: So well, no Art can mend it, for this purpose,
But to thy wit and helpe we're chiefe in debt,
And must liue still beholding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Any honest pitty
I'me willing to bestow vpon poore Ring-doues.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I'le offer no worse play.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Nay and you should sir,
I should draw first and prooue the quicker man,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Hold, there shall neede no weapon at this meeting,
But cause thou shalt not loose thy fury idle,
Heere take this viall, runne vpon the guts,
And end thy quarrell singing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Like a swan aboue bridge,
For looke you heer's the bridge, and heere am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Hold on sweete Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I'ue heard her much commended sir, for one that was nere taught.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: I'me much beholding to 'em, well since you'l needes put'vs together sir, I'le play my part as wel as I can; it shall nere be said I came into a Gentlemans chamber, and let his instru∣ment hang by the walls.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P: Why well said Mol i'faith, it had bene a shame for that Gentleman then, that would haue let it hung still, and nere offred thee it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: There it should haue bene stil then for Mol, for though the world iudge impudently of mee, I nere came into that chamber yet, where I tooke downe the instrument my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.P:
Pish let'em prate abroad, th'art heere where thou art
knowne and lou'd, there be a thousand close dames that wil cal the viall an vnmannerly instrument for a woman, and therefore talke broadly of thee, when you shall haue them sit wider to a worse quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Push, I euer fall a sleepe and thinke not of'em sir, and thus I dreame.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Prithee let's heare thy dreame Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I dreame there is a Mistresse,
And she layes out the money,
Shee goes vnto her Sisters,
Shee neuer comes at any.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Alexander behind them Shee sayes shee went to'th Bursse for patternes, You shall finde her at Saint Katherns, And comes home with neuer a penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: That's a free Mistresse' faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I, I, I, like her that sings it, one of thine own choosing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Here comes a wench will braue ye,
Her courage was so great,
Shee lay with one o'the Nauy,
Her husband lying i'the Fleet.
Yet oft with him she cauel'd,
I wonder what shee ailes,
Her husbands ship lay grauel'd,
When her's could hoyse vp sailes,
Yet shee beganne like all my foes,
To call whoore first: for so do those;
A pox of all false tayles.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Marry amen say I.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: So say I too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Hang vp the viall now sir: all this while I was in a dreame, one shall lie rudely then; but being awake, I keepe my legges together; a watch, what's a clocke here.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Now, now, shee's trapt.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Betweene one and two; nay then I care not: a watch and a musitian are cossen Germanes in one thing, they must both keepe time well, or there's no goodnesse in 'em, the one else deserues to be dasht against a wall, and tother to haue his braines knockt out with a fiddle case, what? a loose chaine and a dangling Diamond.
SP.L: Here were a braue booty for an euening-theefe now,
There's many a younger brother would be glad
To looke twice in at a window for't,
And wriggle in and out, like an eele in a sandbag,
Oh if mens secret youthfull faults should iudge 'em,
'T would be the general'st execution,
SP.P: That ere was seene in England; there would bee but few left to sing the ballets, there would be so much worke: most of our brokers would be chosen for hangmen, a good day for them: they might renew their wardrops of free cost then.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: This is the roaring wench must do vs good.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: No poyson sir but serues vs for some vse, which is confirm'd in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Peace, peace, foot I did here him sure, where ere he be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Who did you heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: My father, 'twas like a sight of his, I must be wary,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: No wilt not be, am I alone so wretched
That nothing takes? I'le put him to his plundge for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Life, heere he comes,—sir I beseech you take it,
Your way of teaching does so much content me,
I'le make it foure pound, here's forty shillings sir.
I thinke I name it right: helpe me good Mol,
Forty in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Sir you shall pardon me,
I haue more of the meanest scholler I can teach,
This paies me more, then you haue offred yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: At the next quarter
When I receiue the meanes my father 'lowes me.
You shall haue tother forty,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: This were well now,
Wer't to a man, whose sorrowes had blind eies,
But mine behold his follies and vntruthes,
With two cleere glasses—how now?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: What's he there?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: You'r come in good time sir, I'ue a suite to you,
I'de craue your present kindnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: What is he there?

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: A Gentleman, a musitian sir, one of excellent fingring▪

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I, I thinke so, I wonder how they scapt her.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Has the most delicate stroake sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: A stroake indeed, I feele it at my heart,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Puts downe all your famous musitians.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I, a whoore may put downe a hundred of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Forty shillings is the agrement sir betweene vs,
Now sir, my present meanes, mounts but to halfe on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: And he stands vpon the whole.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I indeed does he sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: And will doe still, hee'l nere be in other taile,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Therefore I'de stop his mouth sir, and I could,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Hum true, there is no other way indeed,
His folly hardens, shame must needs succeed.
Now sir I vnderstand you professe musique.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I am a poore seruant to that liberall science sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Where is it you teach?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Right against Cliffords Inne.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Hum that's a fit place for it: you haue many schollers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: And some of worth, whom I may call my maisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: I true, a company of whooremaisters; you teach to sing too?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Marry do I sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: I thinke you'l finde an apt scholler of my sonne, es∣pecially for pricke-song.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I haue much hope of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: I am sory for't, I haue the lesse for that: you can play any lesson.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: At first sight sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: There's a thing called the witch, can you play that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: I would be sory any one should mend me in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I, I beleeue thee, thou hast so bewitcht my sonne,
No care will mend the worke that thou hast done,
I haue bethought my selfe since my art failes,
I'le make her pollicy the Art to trap her.
Here are foure Angels markt with holes in them
Fit for his crackt companions, gold he will giue her,
These will I make induction to her ruine,
And rid shame from my house, griefe from my heart
Here sonne, in what you take content and pleasure,
Want shall not curbe you, pay the Gentleman
His latter halfe in gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I thanke you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Oh may the operation an't, end three,
In her, life: shame, in him; and griefe, in mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Faith thou shalt haue'em 'tis my fathers guift,
Neuer was man beguild with better shift.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Hee that can take mee for a male musitian,
I cannot choose but make him my instrument,
And play vpon him.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mistresse Gallipot, and Mistresse Openworke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mi. Gal.
SP.L: Is then that bird of yours (Maister Goshawke) so wild?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: A Goshawke, a Puttocke; all for prey: he angles for fish, but he loues flesh better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Is't possible his smoth face should haue wrinc∣kles in't, and we not see them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Possible? why haue not many handsome legges in silke stockins villanous splay feete for all their great roses?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Troth firra thou saist true.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Op.
SP.P: Didst neuer see an archer (as tho'ast walkt by Bun∣hill) looke a squint when he drew his bow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Yes, when his arrowes haue flin'e toward Isling∣ton, his eyes haue shot cleane contrary towards Pimlico.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: For all the world so does Maister Goshawke dou∣ble with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Oh fie vpon him, if he double once he's not for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Because Goshawke goe▪ in a shag-ruffe band, with a face sticking vp in't, which showes like an agget set in acrampe ring, he thinkes I'me in loue with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: 'Las I thinke he takes his marke amisse in thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: He has by often beating into me made mee be∣leeue that my husband kept a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Swore to me that my husband this very morning went in a boate with a tilt ouer it, to the three pidgions at Brainford, and his puncke with him vnder his tilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: That were wholesome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: I beleeu'd it, fell a swearing at him, curssing of harlots, made me ready to hoyse vp saile, and be there as soone as hee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: So, so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: And for that voyage Goshawke comes hither in∣continently, but sirra this water-spaniell diues after no ducke but me, his hope is hauing mee at Braineford to make mee cry quack.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Art sure of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Sure of it? my poore innocent Openworke came in as I was poking my ruffe, presently hit I him i'the teeth with the three pidgions: he forswore all, I vp and opened all, and now stands he (in a shop hard by) like a musket on a rest, to hit Goshawke i'the eie, when he comes to fetch me to the boate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Such another lame Gelding offered to carry mee through thicke and thinne, (Laxton sirra) but I am ridd of him now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Happy is the woman can bee ridde of 'em all; 'las what are your whisking gallants to our husbands, weigh 'emrightly man for man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Troth meere shallow things.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Idle simple things, running heads, and yet let 'emrun ouer vs neuer so fast, we shop-keepers (when all's done) are sure to haue 'em in our pursnets at length, and when they are in, Lord what simple animalls they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Then they hang head.

SP.SPEAKER: Most. Gal.
SP.L: Then they droupe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Then they write letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Then they cogge.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Then they deale vnder hand with vs, and wee must ingle with our husbands a bed, and wee must sweare they are our cosens, and able to do vs a pleasure at Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: And yet when wee haue donc our best, al's but put into a riuen dish, wee are but frumpt at and libell'd vpon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Oh if it were the good Lords will, there were a law made, no Cittizen should trust any of'em all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Hush sirra, Goshawke flutters.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: How now, are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Nay are you ready? a little thing you see makes vs ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Vs? why, must shee make one i'the voiage?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Oh by any meanes, do I know how my hus∣band will handle mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: 'Foot, how shall I find water, to keepe these two mils going? Well since you'l needs bee clapt vnder hatches, if I sayle not with you both till all split, hang mee vp at the maine yard, & duck mee; it's but lickering them both soundly, & then you shall see their corke heeles flie vp high, like two swannes when their tayles are aboue water, and their long neckes vnder water, diuing to catch gudgions: come, come, oares stand rea∣dy, the tyde's with vs, on with those false faces, blow winds and thou shalt take thy husband, casting out his net to catch fresh Salmon at Brainford.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: I beleeue you'l eate of a coddes head of your owne dressing, before you reach halfe way thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: So, so, follow close, pin as you go.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Do you heare?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Yes, I thanke my eares.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I must haue a bout with your Poticariship,

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: At what weapon?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I must speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax
SP.L: No? you shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Shall? away soust Sturgion, halfe fish, halfe flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: 'Faith gib, are you spitting, I'le cut your tayle pus∣cat for this,

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: 'Las poore Laxton, I thinke thy tayle's cut alrea∣dy: your worst;

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: If I do not,—

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Come, ha'you done?
Sfoote Rosamond, your husband. welcome,

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: How now? sweete Maist. Goshawke, none more
I haue wanted your embracements: when friends meete,
The musique of the spheares sounds not more sweete,
Then does their conferenc: who is this? Rosamond:
Wife: how now sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Silence if you loue mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Why maskt?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Does a maske grieue you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: It does.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Then y'are best get you a mumming.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: S'footeyou'l spoyle all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: May not wee couer our bare faces with maskes
As well as you couer your bald heads with hats?

SP.SPEAKER: Ma. Op.
SP.L: No maskes, why, th'are theeues to beauty, that rob
Of admiration in which true loue lies, (eies
Why are maskes worne? why good? or why desired?
Vnlesse by their gay couers wits are fiered
To read the vild'st lookes; many bad faces,
(Because rich gemmes are treasured vp in cases)
Passe by their priuiledge currant, but as caues
Dambe misers Gold, so maskes are beauties graues,
Men nere meete women with such muffled eies,
But they curse her, that first did maskes deuise,
And sweare it was somebeldame. Come off with't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Good faces maskt are Iewels kept by spirits.
Hide none but bad ones, for they poyson mens sights,
Show then as shop-keepers do their broidred stuffe,
(By owle light) fine wares cannot be open enough,
Prithee (sweete Rose) come strike this sayle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Saile? (eyes:

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Op.
SP.L: Ha? yes wife strike saile, for stormes are in thine

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Th'are here sir in my browes if any rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Ha browes? (what sayes she friend) pray tel me
Your two flagges were aduaunst; the Comedy, (why
Come what's the Comedy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Westward hoe.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: 'Tis Westward hoe shee saies.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Are you both madde?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Is't Market day at Braineford, and your ware not sent vp yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: What market day? what ware?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Apy with three pidgions in't, 'tis drawne and staies your cutting vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: As you regard my credit.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Art madde?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Yes letcherous goate; Baboone.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Baboone? then tosse mee in a blancket,

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Do I it well?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Rarely.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Belike sir shee's not well; best leaue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: No,
I'le stand the storme now how fierce so ere it blow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Did I for this loose all my friends? refuse
Rich hopes, and golden fortunes, to be made
A stale to a common whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: This does amaze mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Oh God, oh God, feede at reuersion now?
A Strumpets leauing?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Rosamond,

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: I sweate, wo'ld I lay in cold harbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Thou hast struck ten thousand daggers through my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Not I by heauen sweete wife. (thee

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Go diuel go; that which thou swear'st by, damnes

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: S'heart will you vndo mee?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: Why stay you heere? the starre, by which you saile, shines yonder aboue Chelsy; you loose your shore if this moone light you: seeke out your light whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Push; your Westerne png.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh,
SP.L: Zounds now hell roares.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.P: With whom you tilted in a paire of oares, this very morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Oares?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: At Brainford sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.P: Racke not my patieuce: Maister Goshawke, some slaue has buzzed this into her, has he not? I run a tilt in Brain∣ford with a woman? 'tis a lie: What old baud tels thee this? S'death 'tis a lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: 'Tis one to thy face shall iustify all that I speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Vd'soule do but name that rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: No sir I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Keepe thee there girle:—then!

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Sister know you this varlet?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Sweare true,
SP.P: Is there a rogueso low damn'd? a second Iudas? a common hang∣man? cutting a mans throate? does it to his face? bite mee be∣hind my backe? a cur dog? sweare if you know this hell-hound.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: In truth I do,

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: His name?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Not for the world;
To haue you to stab him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Oh braue girles: worth Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: A word honest maister Goshawke.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: What do you meane sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.P: Keepe off, and if the diuell can giue a name to this new fury, holla it throngh my eare, or wrap it vp in some hid character: I'le ride to Oxford, and watch out mine eies, but I'leheare the brazen head speak: or else shew me but one haire of his head or beard, that I may sample it; if the siend I mect (in myne owne house) I'le kill him:—the streete.
SP.L: Or at the Church dore:—there—(cause he seekes to vnty
The knot God fastens) he deserues most to dy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: My husband titles him.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Maister Goshawke, pray sir
Sweare to me, that you know him or know hiw not, (wiues,
Who makes me at Brainford to take vp a peticote beside my

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: By heauen that man I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Come, come, you lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Will you not haue all out?
By heauen I know no man beneath the moon
Should do you wrong, but if I had his name,
I'de print it in text letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Print thine owne then,
Did'st not thou sweare to me he kept his whoore?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: And that in sinfull Brainford they would commit
That which our lips did water at sir,—ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Thou spider, that hast wouen thy cunning web
In mine owne house t'insnare me: hast not thou
Suck't nourishment euen vnderneath this roofe,
And turned it all to poyson? spittiug it,
On thy friends face (my husband?) he as t'were sleeping:
Onely to leaue him vgly to mine eies,
That they might glance on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Speake, are these lies?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Mine owne shame me confounds:

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: No more, hee's stung;
Who'd thinke that in one body there could dwell
Deformitie and beauty, (heauen and hell)
Goodnesse I see is but outside, wee all set,
In rings of Gold, stones that be counterfet:
I thought you none.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Pardon mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Truth I doe.
This blemish growes in nature not in you,
For mans creation sticke euen moles in scorne
On fairest cheeks, wife nothing is perfect borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: I thought you had bene borne perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: What's this whole world but a gilt rotten pill?
For at the heart lies the old chore still.
I'le tell you Maister Goshawke, I in your eie
I haue seene wanton fire, and then to try
The soundnesse of my iudgement, I told you
I kept a whoore, made you beleeue 'twas true,
Onely to feele how your pulse beate, but find,
The world can hardly yeeld a perfect friend.
Come, come, a tricke of youth, and 'tis forgiuen,
This rub put by, our loue shall runne more euen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open,
SP.L: You'l deale vpon mens wiues no more?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: No:—you teach me a tricke for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: Troth do not, they'l o're-reach thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mai. Open.
SP.L: Make my house yours sir still.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: I say you shall:
Seeing (thus besieg'd) it holds out, 'twill neuer fall.
SP.STAGE: Enter Maister Gallipot, and Greenewit like a Somner, Laxton muffled a loofo off.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gall.
SP.L: With mee sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.P: You sir? I haue gon snaffling vp and downe by your dore this houre to watch for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: What's the matter husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.P: —I haue caught a cold in my head sir, by sitting vp late in the rose tauerne, but I hope you vnderstand my speech.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: So sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.P: I cite you by the name of Hippocrates Gallipot, and you by the name of Prudence Gallipot, to appeare vpon Crastino, doe you see, Crastino sancti Dunstani (this Easter Tearme) in Bow Church.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gall.
SP.L: Where sir? what saies he?

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.P: Bow: Bow Church, to answere to a libel of precon∣tract on the part and behalfe of the said Prudence and another; y'are best sir take a coppy of the citation, 'tis but tweluepence.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: A Citation?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: You pocky-nosed rascall, what slaue fees you to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Slaue? I ha nothing to do with you, doe you heare sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Laxton ist not?—what fagary is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Trust me I thought sir this storme long ago had bene full laid, when (if you be remembred) I paid you the last fifteene pound, besides the thirty you had first,—for then you swore.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Tush, tush sir, oathes,
Truth yet I'me loth to vexe vou,—tell you what;
Make vp the mony I had an hundred pound,
And take your belly full of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gall.
SP.L: An hundred pound?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: What a 100 pound? he gets none: what a 100 pound?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Sweet Pru be calme, the Gentleman offers thus,
If I will make the monyes that are past
A 100 pound, he will discharge all courts,
And giue his bond neuer to vexe vs more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: A 100 pound? 'Las; take sir but threescore,
Do you seeke my vndoing?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.P: I'le not bate one sixpence,—I'le mall you pusse for spitting.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Do thy worst,
Will fourescore stop thy mouth?

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: Y'are a slaue,
Thou Cheate, I'le now teare mony from thy throat,
Husband lay hold on yonder tauny-coate.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.P: Nay Gentlemen, seeing your woemen are so hote, I must loose my haire in their company I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Ope.
SP.P: His haire sheds off, and yet he speaks not so much in the nose as he did before.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.P: He has had the better Chirurgion, Maister Greenewit, is your wit so raw as to play no better a part then a Somners?

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: I pray who playes a knacke to know an honest man in this company?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gall.
SP.L: Deere husband, pardon me, I did dissemble,
Told thee I was his precontracted wife,
When letters came from him for thirty pound,
I had no shift but that.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: A very cleane shift: but able to make mee lowsy, On.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.P: Husband, I pluck'd (when he had tempted mee to thinke well of him) Get fethers from thy wings, to make him flie more lofty.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gall.
SP.L: A'the top of you wife: on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Gal.
SP.L: He hauing wasted them, comes now for more,
Vsing me as a ruffian doth his whore,
Whose sinne keepes him in breath: by heauen I vow,
Thy bed he neuer wrong'd, more then he does now.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: My bed? ha, ha, like enough, a shop-boord will serue to haue a cuckolds coate cut out vpon: of that wee'l talke hereafter: y'are a villaine▪

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: Heare mee but speake sir, you shall finde mee none.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Pray sir, be patient and heare him.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: I am muzzled for biting sir, vse me how you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: The first howre that your wife was in my eye,
My selfe with other Gentlemen sitting by,
(In your shop) tasting smoake, and speech beng vsed,
That men who haue fairest wiues are most abused,
And hardly scapt the horne, your wife maintain'd
That onely such spots in Citty dames were stain'd,
Iustly, but by mens slanders: for her owne part,
Shee vow'd that you had so much of her heart;
No man by all his wit, by any wile,
Neuer so fine spunne, should your selfe be guile,
Of what in her was yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.P: Yet Pru 'tis well: play out your game at Irish sir: Who winnes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mist. Open.
SP.L: The triall is when shee comes to bearing:

SP.SPEAKER: Lax.
SP.L: I scorn'd one woman, thus, should braue all men,
And (which more vext me) a shee-citizen.
Therefore I laid siege to her, out she held,
Gaue many a braue repulse, and me compel'd
With shame to sound retrait to my hot lust,
Then seeing all base desires rak'd vp in dust,
And that to tempt her modest eares, I swore
Nere to prsumne againe: she said, her eie
Would euer giue me welcome honestly,
And (since I was a Gentlman) if it runne low,
Shee would my state relieue, not to o'rethrow
Your owne and hers: did so; then seeing I wrought
Vpon her meekenesse, mee she set at nought,
And yet to try if I could turne that tide,
You see what streme I stroue with, but sir I sweare
By heauen, and by those hopes men lay vp there,
I neither haue, nor had a base intent
To wrong your bed, what's done, is meriment:
Your Gold I pay backe with this interest,
When I had most power to do't I wroug'd you least.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: If this no gullery be sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: No, no, on my life,

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Then sir I am beholden (not to you wife)
But Maister Laxton to your want of doing ill,
Which it seemes you haue not Gentlemen,
Tarry and dine here all.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Open.
SP.L: Brother, we haue a iest,
As good as yours to furnish out a feast.

SP.SPEAKER: Maist. Gal.
SP.L: Wee'l crowne our table with it: wife brag no more,
Of holding out: who most brags is most whore.
SP.STAGE: Enter Iacke Dapper, Moll, Sir Beautious Ganymed, and Sir Thomas Long.

SP.SPEAKER: Iacke Dap.
SP.P: But prethee Maister Captaine Iacke be plaine and perspicuous with mee; was it your Megge of Westminsters courage, that rescued mee from the Poultry puttockes indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P:
The valour of my wit I ensure you sir fetcht you off brauely, when you werre i'the forlorne hope among those desperates, Sir Bewtious Ganymed here, and sir Thomas Long heard that cuckoe (my man Trapdore) sing the note of your
ransome from captiuty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bewt.
SP.L: Vds so Mol, where's that Trapdore?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Hang'd I thinke by this time, a Iustice in this towne, (that speakes nothing but make a Mittimus a way with him to Newgate) vsed that rogue like a fire-worke to run vpon a line betwixt him and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: how, how?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Marry to lay traines of villany to blow vp my life; I smelt the powder, spy'd what linstocke gaue fire to shoote against the poore Captaine of the Gallifoyst, & away slid I my man, like a shouell-board shilling, hee stroutes vp and downe the suburbes I thinke: and eates vp whores: feedes vpon a bauds garbadg.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.L: Sirra Iacke Dapper.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac, Dap.
SP.L: What sai'st Tom Long?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.P: Thou hadst a sweet fac't boy haile fellow with thee to your little Gull: how is he spent?

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: Troth I whistled the poore little buzzard of a my fist, because when hee wayted vpon mee at the ordinaries, the gallants hit me i'the teeth still, and said I lookt like a painted Aldermans tomb, and the boy at my elbow like a deaths head. Sirra Iacke, Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: What saies my little Dapper?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bewt.
SP.L: Come, come, walke and talke, walke and talke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.L: Mol and I'le be i'the midst.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: These Knights shall haue squiers places belike then: well Dapper what say y ou?

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: Sirra Captaine mad Mary, the gull my owne fa∣ther (Dapper) Sir Dauy) laid these London boote-halers the catch poles in ambush to set vpon mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Your father? away Iacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: By the tassels of this handkercher 'tis true, and what was his warlicke stratageme thinke you? hee thought be∣cause a wicker cage tames a nightingale, a lowsy prison could make an asse of mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: A nasty plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P:
I; as though a Counter, which is a parke, in which
all the wilde beasts of the Citty run head by head could tame mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Yonder comes my Lord Noland.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Saue you my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.P: Well met Gentlemen all, good Sir Bewtious Gany∣med, Sir Thomas Long?, and how does Maister Dapper?

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.L: Thankes my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: No Tobacco my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol
SP.L: No faith Iacke.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: My Lord Noland will you goe to Pimlico with vs? wee are making a boone voyage to that appy land of spice-cakes

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.P: Heeres such a merry ging, I could find in my heart to saile to the worlds end with such company, come Gentle∣men let's on.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.L: Here's most amorous weather my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Amorous weather.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.L: Is not amorous a good word?
SP.STAGE: Enter Trapdore like a poore Souldier with a pateh o're one eie, and Teare-Cat with him, all tatters.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Shall we set vpon the infantry, these troopes of foot? Zounds yonder comes Mol my whoorish Maister & Mistresse, wold I had her kidneys betweene my teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Tear-Cat.
SP.L: I had rather haue a cow heele.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Zounds I am so patcht vp, she cannot discouer mee: wee'l on.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: Alla corago then.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Good your Honours, and Worships, enlarge the eares of commiseration, and let the sound of a hoarse military or∣gan-pipe, penetrate your pittiful bowels to extract out of them so many small drops of siluer, as may giue a hard strawbed lod∣ging to a couple of maim'd souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Iacke Dap.
SP.L: Where are you maim'd?

SP.SPEAKER: T Cat.
SP.L: In both our neather limbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Come, come, Dapper, lets giue 'em something, las poore men, what mony haue you? by my troth I loue a souldier with my soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bewt.
SP.L: Stay, stay, where haue you seru'd?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.L: In any part of the Low countries?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Not in the Low countries, if it please your manhood, but in Hungarie against the Turke at the siedge of Belgrad.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Who seru'd there with you sirra?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Many Hungarians, Moldauians, Valachians, and Tran∣siluanians, with some Sclauonians, and retyring home sir, the Ve∣netian Gallies tooke vs prisoners, yet free'd vs, and suffered vs to beg vp and downe the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.L: You haue ambled all ouer Italy then.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Oh sir, from Venice to Roma, Uecchio, Bononia, Romania, Bolonia, Modena, Piacenza, and Tuscana, with all her Cities, as Pistoia, Valteria, Mountepulchena, Arrezzo, with the Siennois, and diuerse others.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Meere rogues, put spurres to 'em once more.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: Thou look'st like a strange creature, a fat butter∣box, yet speak'st English,
SP.L: What art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: Ick mine Here. Ick bin den ruffling Teare-Cat.
Den, braue Soldade, Ick bin dorick all Dutchlant.
Gueresen: Der Shellum das meere Ine Beasa
Ine woert gaeb.
Ick slaag vin stroakes ou tom Cop.
Dastick Den hundred touzun Diuell halle,
Frollick miue Here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bewt.
SP.L: Here, here, let's be rid of their iobbering,

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Not a crosse Sir Bewtiout, you base rogues, I haue taken measure of you, better then a taylor can, and I'le fit you, as you (monster with one eie) haue fitted mee,

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Your Worship will not abuse a souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: Souldier? thou deseru'st to bee hang'd vp by that tongue which dishonours so noble a profession, souldier you skeldering varlet? hold, stand, there should be a trapdore here abouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: The balles of these glasiers of mine (mine eyes) shall be shot vp and downe in any hot peece of seruice for my inuincible Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Iacke Dap.
SP.P: I did not thinke there had bene such knauery in blacke patches as now I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Oh sir he hath bene brought vp in the Ile of dogges, and can both fawne like a Spaniell, and bite like a Mastiue, as hee finds occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: What are you sirra? a bird of this feather too.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: A man beaten from the wars sir.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.L: I thinke so, for you neuer stood to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Iac. Dap.
SP.L: What's thy name fellow souldier?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: I am cal'd by those that haue seen my valour, Tear-Cat.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Teare-Cat?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.P: A meere whip-Iacke, and that is in the Common-wealth of rogues, a slaue, that can talke of sea-fight, name all your chiefe Pirats, discouer more countries to you, then either the Dutch, Spanish, French, or English euer found out, yet in∣deed all his seruice is by land, and that is to rob a Faire, or some such venturous exploit; Teare-Cat, foot sirra I haue your name now I remember me in my booke of horners, hornes for the thumbe, you know how.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.P: No indeed Captaine Mol (for I know you by sight) I am no such nipping Christian, but a maunderer vpon the pad I confesse, and meeting with honest Trapdore here, whom you had cashierd from bearing armes, out at elbowes vnder your colours, I instructed him in the rudements of roguery, and by my map made him saile ouer any Country you can name, so that now he can maunder better then my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.L: So then Trapdore thou art turn'd souldier now.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Alas sir, now there's no warres, 'tis the safest course of life I could take.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P:
I hope then you can cant, for by your cudgels, you
sirra are an vpright man.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: As any walkes the hygh way I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: And Teare-Cat what are you? a wilde rogue, an an∣gler, or a ruffler?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.P: Brother to this vpright man, flesh and bloud, ruf∣fling Teare-Cat is my name, and a ruffler is my stile, my title, my profession.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Sirra where's your Doxy, halt not with mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Doxy Mol, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: His wench.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: My doxy I haue by the Salomon a doxy, that carries a kitchin mort in her slat at her backe, besides my dell and my dainty wilde del, with all whom I'le tumble this next dark∣mans in the strommel, and drinke ben baufe, and eate a fat gruntling cheate, a cackling cheate, and a quacking cheate.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.L: Here's old cheating.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: My doxy stayes for me in a bousing ken, braue Cap∣taine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Hee sayes his wench staies for him in an alehouse: you are no pure rogues.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.P: Pure rogues? no, wee scorne to be pure rogues, but if you come to our lib ken, or our stalling ken, you shall finde neither him nor mee, a quire cuffin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: So sir, no churle of you.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: No, but a ben caue, a braue caue, a gentry cuffin.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Call you this canting?

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: Zounds, I'le giue a schoolemaister halfe a crowne a week, and teach mee this pedlers French.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Do but strowle sir, halfe a haruest with vs sir, and you shall gabble your belly-full.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Come you rogue cant with me.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.P: Well sayd Mol, cant with her sirra, and you shall haue mony, else not a penny.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I'le haue a bout if she please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Come on sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P:
Ben mort, shall you and I heaue a booth, mill a ken or nip a bung, and then wee'l couch a hogshead vnder the Ruffe∣mans,
and there you shall wap with me, & Ile niggle with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Out you damn'd impudent rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Cut benar whiddes, and hold your fambles and your stampes.

SP.SPEAKER: L Nol.
SP.P: Nay, nay, Mol, why art thou angry? what was his gibberish?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Marry this my Lord sayes hee; Ben mort (good wench) shal you and I heaue a booth, mill a ken, or nip a bung? shall you and I rob a house, or cut a purse?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Very Good. (mans:

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: And then wee'l couch a hogshead vnder the Ruffe-
And then wee'l lie vnder a hedge.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: That was my desire Captaine, as 'tis fit a souldier should lie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: And there you shall wap with mee, and I'le niggle with you, and that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bewt.
SP.L: Nay, nay Mol what's that wap?

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: Nay teach mee what niggling is, I'de faine bee niggling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Wapping and niggling is all one, the rogue my man can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: 'Tis fadoodling: if it please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bewt.
SP.L: This is excellent, one fit more good Moll,

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Come you rogue sing with me.
A gage of ben Rom-bouse
In a bousing ken of Rom-vile.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: Is Benar then a Caster,
Pecke, pennam, lay or popler,
Which we mill in deuse a vile.
Oh I wud lib all the lightmans.
Oh I woud lib all the darkemans,
By the sollamon vnder the Ruffemans.
By the sollamon in the Hartmans.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: And scoure the Quire cramp ring,
And couch till a pallyard docked my dell,
So my bousy nab might skew rome bouse well
Auast to the pad, let vs bing,
Auast to the pad, let vs bing.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Fine knaues i'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: The grating of ten new cart-wheeles, and the gruntling of fiue hundred hogs cōming from Rumford mar∣ket, cannot make a worse noyse then this canting language does in my eares; pray my Lord Noland, let's giue these soul∣diers their pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Bewt.
SP.L: Agreed, and let them march.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Heere Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Now I see that you are stal'd to the rogue, and are not ashamed of your professions, looke you: my Lord Noland heere and these Gentlemen, bestowes vpon you two, two boordes and a halfe, that's two shillings sixe pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Thankes to your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: Thankes heroicall Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Away.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Wee shall cut ben whiddes of your Maisters and Mi∣streship, wheresoeuer we come.

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: You'l maintaine sirra the old Iustices plot to his face.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Else trine me on the cheats: hang me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Be sure you meete mee there.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.P: Without any more maundring I'le doo't, follow braue Tear-Cat.
SP.STAGE: Exeunt they two manet the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Cat.
SP.L: I prae, sequor, let vs go mouse.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Mol what was in that canting song? (onely milke

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Troth my Lord, onely a praise of good drinke, the
Which these wilde beasts loue to sucke, and thus it was:
A rich cup of wine, oh it is iuyce Diuine,
More wholesome for the head,: hen meate, drinke, or bread,
To fill my drunken pate, with that, I'de sit vp late,
By the heeles wou'd I lie, vnder a lowsy hedge die,
Let a slaue haue a pull at my whore, so I be full
Of that precious liquor; And a parcell of such stuffe my Lord
Not worth the opening.
SP.STAGE: Enter a Cutpurse very gallant, with foure or fiue men after him, one with a wand.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: What gallant comes yonder?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.L: Masse I thinke I know him, 'tis one of Cumberland.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cut.
SP.P: Shall we venture to shuffle in amongst yon heap of Gallants, and strike?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cut.
SP.P: 'Tis a question whether there bee any siluer shels amongst them, for all their sattin outsides.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Let's try?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Pox on him, a gallant? shaddow mee, I know him: 'tis one that cumbers the land indeed; if hee swimme neere to the shore of any of your pockets, looke to your purses.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: This braue fellow is no bettet then a foyst.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Foyst, what's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: A diuer with two fingers, a picke-pocket; all his traine study the figging law, that's to say; cutting of purses and foysting; one of them is a nip, I tooke him once i'the twopen∣ny gallery at the Fortune; then there's a cloyer, or snap, that dogges any new brother in that trade, and snappes will haue halfe in any booty; Hee with the wand is both a stale, whose office is, to face a man i'the streetes, whil'st shels are drawne by an other, and then with his blacke coniuring rod in his hand, he by the nimblenesse of his eye and iugling sticke, will in chea∣ping a peece of plate at a goldsmithes stall, make foure or fiue ringes mount from the top of his caduceus, and as if it were at leape-frog, they skip into his hand presently.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cut.
SP.L: Zounds wee are smoakt.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cut.
SP.P: Wee are boyl'd, pox on her; see Moll the roaring drabbe.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cut.
SP.L: All the diseases of sixteene hospitals boyle her: away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Blesse you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cut.
SP.L: And you good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Do'st not ken mee man?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cut.
SP.L: No trust mee sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.P: Heart, there's a Knight to whom I'me bound for many fauours, lost his purse at the last new play i'the Swanne, seuen Angels in't, make it good you'r best; do you see? no more.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cut.
SP.P: A Sinagogue shall be cal'd Mistresse Mary, disgrace mee not; pacus palabros, I will coniure for you, farewell:

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Did not I tell you my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.P: I wonder how thou cam'st to the knowledge of these nasty villaines.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.P: And why doe the foule mouthes of the world call thee Mol cutpursse? a name, me thinkes, damn'd and odious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Dare any step forth to my face and say,
I haue tane thee doing so Mol? I must confesse,
In younger dayes, when I was apt to stray,
I haue sat amongst such adders; seene their stings,
As any here might, and in full play-houses
Watcht their quicke-diuing hands, to bring to shame
Such rogues, and in that streame met an ill name:
When next my Lord you spie any one of those,
So hee bee in his Art a scholler, question him,
Tempt him with gold to open the large booke
Of his close villanies: and you your selfe shall cant
Better then poore Mol can, and know more lawes
Of cheaters, lifters, nips, foysts, puggards, curbers,
Withall the diuels blacke guard, then it is fit
Should be discouered to a noble wit.
I know they haue their orders, offices,
Circuits and circles, vnto which they are bound,
To raise their owne damnation in.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.L: How do'st thou know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: As you do, I shew it you, they to me show it.
Suppose my Lord you were in Venice.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: If some Italian pander there would tell
All the close trickes of curtizans; would not you
Hearken to such a fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: And here,
Being come from Uenice, to a friend most deare
That were to trauell thither, you would proclaime
Your knowledge in those villanies, to saue
Your friend from their quicke danger: must you haue
A blacke ill name, because ill things you know,
Good troth my Lord, I am made Mol cut purse so.
How many are whores, in small ruffes and still lookes?
How many chast, whose names fill slanders bookes?
Were all men cuckolds, whom gallants in their scornes
Cal so, we should not walke for goring hornes,
Perhaps for my madde going some reproue mee,
I please my selfe, and care not else who loues mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes
SP.L: A braue minde Mol i'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Long.
SP.L: Come my Lord, shal's to the Ordinary?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: I, 'tis noone sure. (or to the world:

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Good my Lord, let not my name condemne me to you
A fencer I hope may be cal'd a coward, is he so for that?
If all that haue ill names in London, were to be whipt, (ther
And to pay but twelue pence a peece to the beadle, I would ra-
Haue his office, then a Constables.

SP.SPEAKER: Iack. Dap.
SP.P: So would I Captaine Moll: 'twere a sweete tick∣ling office i'faith.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Alexander Wengraue, Goshawke and Greenewit, and others.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: My sonne marry a theefe, that impudent girle,
Whom all the world sticke their worst eyes vpon?

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: How will your care preuent it?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: 'Tis impossible.
They marry close, thei'r gone, but none knowes whether.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Oh Gentlemen, when ha's a fathers heart-strings
Held out so long from breaking: now what newes sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Seruant.
SP.L: They were met vppo'th water an houre since, sir,
Putting in towards the Sluce.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: The Sluce? come Gentlemen,
'Tis Lambith workes against vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.P: And that Lambith, ioynes more mad matches, then your sixe wet townes, twixt that and Windsor-bridge, where fares lye soaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Delay no time sweete Gentlemen: to Blacke Fryars,
Wee'l take a paire of Oares and make after 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: Your sonne, and that bold masculine rampe
My mistresse, are landed now at Tower.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Hoyda, at Tower?

SP.SPEAKER: Trap.
SP.L: I heard it now reported.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Which way Gentlemen shall I bestow my care?
I'me drawne in peeces betwixt deceipt and shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-Alla.
SP.L: Sir Alexander.
You'r well met, and most rightly serued,
My daughter was a scorne to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Say not so fir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: A very abiect, shee poore Gentlewoman,
Your house had bene dishonoured. Giue you ioy sir,
Of your sons Gaskoyne-Bride, you'l be a Grandfather shortly
To a fine crew of roaring sonnes and daughters,
'Twill helpe to stocke the suburbes passing well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: O play not with the miseries of my heart,
Wounds should be drest and heal'd, not vext, or left
Wide open, to the anguish of the patient,
And scornefull aire let in: rather let pitty
And aduise charitably helpe to refresh 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: Who'd place his charity so vnworthily.
Like one that giues almes to a cursing beggar,
Had I but found one sparke of goodnesse in you
Toward my deseruing child, which then grew fond
Of your sonnes vertues, I had cased you now.
But I perceiue both fire of youth and goodnesse,
Are rak'd vp in the ashes of your age,
Else no such shame should haue come neere your house,
Nor such ignoble sorrowe touch your heart,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: If not for worth, for pitties sake assist mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: You vrge a thing past sense, how can he helpe you?
All his assistance is as fraile as ours,
Full as vncertaine, where's the place that holds 'em?
One brings vs waer-newes; then comes an other
With a full charg'd mouth, like a culuerins voyce,
And he reports the Tower; whose sounds are truest?

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: In vaine you flatter him sir Alexander.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: I flatter him, Gentlemen you wrong mee grosly.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene,
SP.L: Hee doe's it well i'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: Both newes are false,
Of Tower or water: they tooke no such way yet. (plundges?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Oh strange: heare you this Gentlemen, yet more

SP.SPEAKER: Fiz-Alla.
SP.P: Th'are neerer then you thinke for yet more close, then if they were further off.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: How am I lost in these distractions?

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-Alla.
SP.L: For your speeches Gentlemen,
In taxing me for rashnesse; fore you all,
I will engage my state to halfe his wealth,
Nay to his sonnes reuenewes, which are lesse,
And yet nothing at all, till they come from him;
That I could (if my will stucke to my power),
Preuent this mariage yet, nay banish her
For euer from his thoughts, much more his armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Slacke not this goodnesse, though you heap vpon me
Mountaines of malice and reuenge hereafter:
I'de willingly resigne vp halfe my state to him,
So he would marry the meanest drudge I hire.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: Hee talkes impossibilites, and you beleeue 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-Alla.
SP.L: I talke no more, then I know how to finish,
My fortunes else are his that dares stake with me,
The poore young Gentleman I loue and pitty:
And to keepe shame from him, (because the spring
Of his affection was my daughters first,
Till his frowne blasted all,) do but estate him
In those possessions, which your loue and care
Once pointed out for him, that he may haue roome,
To entertaine fortunes of noble birth,
Where now his desperate wants casts him vpon her:
And if I do not for his owne sake chiefly,
Rid him of this disease, that now growes on him,
I'le forfeit my whole state, before these Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: Troth but you shall not vndertake such matches,
Wee'l perswade so much with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Heere's my ring,
He will beleeue this token: fore these Gentlemen,
I will confirme it fully: all those lands,
My first loue lotted him, he shall straight possesse
In that refusall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: If I change it not, change mee into a beggar.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: Are you mad sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: 'Tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Will you vndoe your selfe by doing,
And shewe a prodigall tricke in your old daies?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: 'Tis a match Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: I, I, sir I.
I akse no fauour; trust to you for none,
My hope rests in the goodnesse of your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: Hee holds it vp well yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Of an old knight i'faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Curst be the time, I laid his first loue barren,
Wilfully barren, that before this houre
Had sprung forth friutes, of comfort and of honour;
He lou'd a vertuous Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Life, heere's Mol.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: Iack.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: How dost thou Iacke?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: How dost thou Gallant?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Impudence, where's my sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Moll.
SP.L: Weakensse, go looke him.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Is this your wedding gowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: The man talkes monthly:
Hot broth and a darke chamber for the knight,
I see hee'l be starke mad at our next meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Why sir, take comfort now, there's no such matter,
No Priest will marry her, sir, for a woman,
Whiles that shape's on, and it was neuer knowne,
Two men were married and conioyn'd in one:
Your sonne hath made some shift to loue another.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: What ere' she be, she has my blessing with her,
May they be rich, and fruitfull, and receiue
Like comfort to their issue, as I take in them,
Ha's pleas'd me now, marrying not this,
Through a whole world he could not chuse amisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: Glad y'are so penitent, for your former sinne sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: Say he should take a wench with her smocke-dowry,
No portion with her, but her lips and armes?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Why? who thriue better sir? they haue most blessing,
Though other haue more wealth, and least repent,
Many that want most, know the most content.

SP.SPEAKER: Greene.
SP.L: Say he should marry a kind youthfull sinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Age will quench that, any offence but theft and drun-
Nothing but death can wipe away. (kennesse,
There sinnes are greene, euen when there heads are gray,
Nay I dispaire not now, my heart's cheer'd Gentlemen,
No face can come vnfortunately to me,
Now sir, your newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Seruant.
SP.L: Your sonne with his faire Bride is neere at hand,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Faire may their fortunes be.

SP.SPEAKER: Green.
SP.L: Now you'r resolu'd sir, it was neuer she,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: I finde it in the musicke of my heart,
SP.STAGE: Enter Mol maskt, in Sebastians hand, and Fitz-Allard.
SP.L: See where they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Gosh.
SP.L: A proper lusty presence sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Now has he pleas'd me right, I alwaies counseld him
To choose a goodly personable creature,
Iust of her pitch was my first wife his mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Before I dare discouer my offence, I kneele for pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex;
SP.L: My heart gaue it thee, before thy tongue could aske it,
Rise, thou hast rais'd my ioy to greater height.
Then to that seat where griefe deiected it,
Both welcome to my loue, and care for euer,
Hide not my happinesse too long, al's pardoned,
Here are our friends, salute her, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Heart, who this Mol?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: O my reuiuing shame, is't I must liue,
To be strucke blind, be it the worke of sorrow,
Before age take't in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-All.
SP.L: Darkenesse and death.
Haue you deceau'd mee thus? did I engage
My whole estate for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: You askt no fauour,
And you shall finde as little, since my comforts,
Play false with me, I'le be as cruell to thee
As griefe to fathers hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Why what's the matter with you?
Lesse too much ioy, should make your age forgetfull,
Are you too well, too happy?

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: With a vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Me thinkes you should be proud of such a daughter,
As good a man, as your sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: O monstrous impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: You had no note before, an vnmarkt Kinght,
Now all the towne will take regard on you,
And all your enemies feare you for my sake,
You may passe where you list, through crowdes most thicke,
And come of brauely with your pursse vnpickt,
You do not know the benefits I bring with mee,
No cheate dares worke vpon you, with thumbe or knife,
While y'aue a roaring girle to your sonnes wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: A diuell rampant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fitz-Alla.
SP.L: Haue you so much charity?
Yet to release mee of my last rash bargaine,
And I'le giue in your pledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: No sir, I stand to't, I'le worke vpon aduantage,
As all mischiefes do vpon mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Aitz-All.
SP.L: Content, beare witnesse all then
His are the lands, and so contention ends.
Here comes your sonnes Bride, twixt two noble friends.
SP.STAGE: Enter the Lord Noland, and Sir Bewtious Ganymed, with Ma∣ry Fitz-Allard betweene them, the Cittizens and their wiues with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Now are you gull'd as you would be, thanke me for't,
I'de a fore-singer in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: Forgiue mee father,
Though there before your eyes my sorrow fain'd,
This still was shee, for whom true loue complain'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Blessings eternall, and the ioyes of Angels,
Beginne your peace heere, to be sign'd in heauen,
How short my sleepe of sorrow seemes now to me,
To this eternity of boundlesse comforts,
That finds no want but vtterance, and expression.
My Lord your office heere appeares so honourably:
So full of ancient goodnesse, grace, and worthinesse,
I neuer tooke more ioy in sight of man,
Then in your comfortable presence now.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Nor I more delight in doing grace to vertue,
Then in this worthy Gentlewoman, your sonnes Bride,
Noble Fitz-Alards daughter, to whose honour
And modest fame, I am a seruant vow'd,
So is this Knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: Your loues make my ioyes proud,
Bring foorth those deeds of land, my care layd ready,
And which, old knight, thy noblenesse may challenge,
Ioyn'd with thy daughters vertues, whom I prise now,
As deerely as that flesh, I call myne owne.
Forgiue me worthy Gentlewoman, 'twas my blindnesse
When I reiected thee, I saw thee not,
Sorrow and wilfull rashnesse grew like filmes
Ouer the eyes of iudgement, now so cleere
I see the brightnesse of thy worth appeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.L: Duty and loue may I deserue in those,
And all my wishes haue a perfect close,

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.L: That tongue can neuer erre, the sound's so sweete,
Here honest sonne, receiue into thy hands,
The keyes of wealth, possession of those lands,
Which my first care prouided, thei'r thine owne,
Heauen giue thee a blessing with 'em, the best ioyes,
That can in worldly shapes to man betide,
Are fertill lands, and a faire fruitfull Bride,
Of which I hope thou'rt sped.

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: I hope so too sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Father and sonne, I ha'done you simple seruice here,

SP.SPEAKER: Seb.
SP.L: For which thou shalt not part Moll vnrequited.

SP.SPEAKER: Alex.
SP.P: Thou art a madd girle, and yet I cannot now con∣demne thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Condemne mee? troth and you should sir,
I'de make you seeke out one to hang in my roome,
I'de giue you the slip at Gallowes, and cozen the people.
Heard you this iest my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: What is it Iacke?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: He was in feare his sonne would marry mee,
But neuer dreamt that I would nere agree.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Nol.
SP.L: Why? thou had'st a suiter once Iacke, when wilt marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mol.
SP.L: Who I my Lord, I'le tell you when ifaith,
